Update: After escalating this issue, Fossil did in fact provide a replacement. I've changed my overall rating to reflect that their customer service did the fair thing in the end since the watch malfunction wasn't my fault and I allowed them twice to repair it. It is a great watch when it worked and I would recommend it in that context. My watch keeps rebooting requiring a reset which only stops the issue temporarily. I sent it in for warranty service twice and it still is not fixed. I contacted Fossil a third time requesting a replacement because I really like the watch when it works. THEIR reponse is it is now out of warranty and I AM responsible for any costs incurred for repair for this existing issue that never was fixed under warranty (so no replacement obviously). Disappointed to say the least. I'll post any update but for now, I'd stay away from Fossil smartwatch products.

I previously had a Garmin Fenix 3 HR but wasn't using most the functionality on it and wanted a more attractive everyday watch.  Based on reviews, I settled on the Fossil Carlyle Gen 5. What a difference. Instead of being clunky and slow and quite ugly, it's fast and smooth and beautiful with a great feel and screen. The OS is smooth and easy to use, but boy do you pay for it in battery life.  Out of the box this thing was burning through maybe 1% every few minutes, just by being on my wrist doing nothing.
 When I started interacting with it to explore it the battery was going down even faster, maybe 10% in 10 minutes. I read of many similar complaints and there are Reddit threads discussing how to get reasonable battery life from it. In the end I used the custom battery mode option where I disabled pretty much everything apart from Bluetooth and always on screen and the things you can't turn off like heart rate; no location, wifi, tilt to wake , NFC, ok Google etc.  I didn't want most of those anyway. Wow. What a difference. Now I make it home after a full day at work (maybe 12h) with 60+% battery remaining.  I charge twice a day, whilst I shower in the morning, and half an hour or so before bed. Bi use sleep as Android for sleep movement and heart rate tracking with the watch and that similarly uses ~40% battery overnight. Mostly I use the watch for the time and controlling music; I have all but a few notifications turned off, so in truth other than heartrate monitoring it doesn't do much "smart", so from that perspective the battery life is dreadful, but it gets me through a day of regular usage which is acceptable. If you think you're going to track hikes or navigate via gps from it, or spend hours playing around with it, don't buy.  You'll be disappointed. I'm keeping my Garmin for outdoor use and using this for daily wear. Fossil, change your default battery mode; I nearly returned this it was SO BAD out of the box.  And for goodness sake make it a little thicker and put some more juice in it.
Purchased for my boyfriend and he loves it, it has a large display, he can receive all his notifications, it has a pretty good battery life, it’s water resistant and the app makes it easy to set up.

A few months ago I saw some family checking messages on a watched so I did some light research and chose this specific watch. I wear it daily and absolutely fell in love with it's functionality and easy of use. Being google compatible made this watch for me since the rest of my house is google enabled. Being able to have a voice command on my wrist to set timers for work, play music, check messages and take calls is great. The little speaker on there isn't bad and the mic picks up commands well too. My favorite low key feature is when I'm playing music on my phone to my portable speaker I can leave both on the charger and literally adjust the volume with the dial on the watch and tap to change songs! It also houses a small amount of apps from the Google play store that have a few time passing games as well. Also, if you have picture text messages on your phone they'll display on this watch as well. Google fit enabled so the heart rate and exercise info syncs with the phone and scale in the restroom. I also like the theater mode to have it hush and dim while watching movies. Lastly to end my rambling, asking google to find my phone from this watch has saved me so much time since I tend to actually misplace my phone around the house. Great impression and I don't see myself replacing it for a very long time at this rate.

I got this watch in January 2021 after my Galaxy S2 died, and it seemed ok. I specifically wanted Google Assistant, heart rate monitoring, and notifications from my phone--and it delivered on all of those. A few things seemed lacking, and I got the opportunity to try the Fitbit Versa 3--which revealed how bad this watch really is. Here are my findings as of August 2021: Battery life. The Fossil Gen 5 originally lasted 1.5-2 days, in less than 4 months it started going into battery saving mode by 7pm. I charge it every night, so it's definitely not able to do sleep tracking during that time. I was accustomed to charging my Galaxy S2 every night, even though it would last 2-3 days on a charge, so that wasn't a big deal--until I got the Fitbit V3. The Fitbit's charge has only dropped ~10% per day (full day with sleep tracking all night) and charges 9% during a quick shower after my morning workout. There is absolutely no comparison. Alarms. I spent hours trying to get my phone alarms to stop duplicating on the watch. My options were to disconnect from the watch every evening, endure duplicate alarms from my phone and watch every morning, or let it charge in the other room. I opted to let it charge in my office. Voice Assistant. The voice assistant technically works, but I would find myself repeating the same commands 3-4 times slowly before it would take. I assumed this was the cost of having a mic inside a watch, but my Fitbit V3 has no difficulty hearing me the first time--every time. Heart Rate Monitoring. It has a heart rate monitor, and it will check occasionally--or when explicitly told to. I assumed that's what the heart rate monitor was supposed to do, but the Fitbit V3 actually increases the sampling rate when I'm exercising and reads far more often--giving me much more confidence in the data. Buttons. When I do pushups, the button on the Fossil does a long-press on my wrist and sometimes the button sticks--requiring me to pull it back out. It's only 7 months old! Notifications. It did notifications just fine, but so does the Fitbit V3. A few months ago, friend of mine wanted to get a smartwatch and asked me if I'd recommend my watch. At the time, I said, "It depends on what you want the watch for. This watch is optimized for the things I'm using it for, but I can't recommend it for general use." Now I can confidently say, no. I don't recommend it. Get a Fitbit Versa 3 or something that's even on the same playing field.

I love this watch so much!  It looks great, the love the features, its easy to use.  There is very little about it that I dislike.  however, There is a glitch that persisted on my other Fossil smartwatch as well that causes the watch to randomly shut off.  The only way to turn it back on is to put it on the charger for a few moments.  The battery is NOT dead either.  The watch usually has a high charge after it turns back on.  This is very frustrating and really takes away from a genuinly great product.  Please fix this issue, Fossil!

First the good parts. I like the look of this watch (I have the smoke color). I think it looks better in "real life" than in the photos.  It is a nice size (I am not a big person), and I like that I can easly put any 22mm band on it.  Also, the display is crisp and bright. It even squeeks by in bright sun. On the other side, the battery and battery management are marginal. There are four battery profiles.  The default profile, named "daily" won't get me through a typical day without an afternoon top-up.  Two other profiles, "extended" and "time only", turn off the "always on display", which is unacceptable to me.  That leaves the "custom" display. I use it with the display & bluetooth on, location (gps and compass) on or off as I need them, and just about everything else off.  This gets me through a day with some power to spare. But I have to pay attention.  I'm also not convinced, based on watching the battery drain, that the software is telling me everything about what battery things are on or off.  I find it necessary to "re-assert" the custom profile every so often. Overall I like this watch, but I think we have a ways to go before smart watches are more than a tech toy.

Update 12/1/2023:
----------------------
The watch finally died abruptly while wearing last night. It was 90% charge as I took it out of the charger a little while ago. Went cold dead. After the original review below, I managed the settings such that with most connectivities off it would last full day. So I was okay and I bought a couple of dozens of watch faces and used to change them often. Also bought additional charging stands chargers and bands. Down the drain. They are not super expensive. But they are all pile of garbage now at home all of a sudden. Original Review:
-------------------
I have seen smart watches on other people for years and stuck to my old fashioned Seiko analog. Finally, I bought this one after looking around reviews and comparison. Apple watch wasn't an option for me. We have dozens of Android but no Apple devices. Now, the watch does work per spec. That wasn't the reason for my lower than 5 ?? rating. I rated for what value I derive and satisfaction with the use. 1. The watch is bulkier than my old fashioned watch. Not very aesthetically pleasing. Although, this looked better/sober among various models. This is minor. I don't dislike it, at the same time not overly enthusiastic to wear it. 2. It took some time to understand the quirks of how this watch behaves for the first time. This is not a complaint. Being a techie, I pick up fairly quickly. 3. Google Pay on the watch requires screen lock for security. The logic is understandable, but ridiculous for a watch to be unlocked frequently. Google has to find a way to drive security from phone to watch differently. Don't know how. But there must be a user friendly option. This is just bizarre. 4. Watch screen. This is the problematic part. Apparently, the watch makers can only squeeze in so much battery power. Hence, there is a whole bunch of ways they try to save power so that it lasts for a day's use. And as a result, their automatic screen brightness is pathetic. You can barely see it. 5. Watch faces. The initial euphoria of being able to change faces wears out very quickly when you realize that there are very few useful faces delivered with the watch. The list of faces are plain ridiculous and cartoonish to my taste. May be good for others. I like clean faces with analog clock and digital info snippets. Found only one I could use. Then I started scavenging the app store. Because, they advertise that they got tens of thousands! Well, after I kept paying, I realized that not all are compatible to my watch. And finally, I realized that the sane way to look for new watch faces is to stick to the included apps in the watch suggested list within the app store inside the watch. Install others on phone and hope to use on phone will often cause a huge waste of time and money with suboptimal experience. 6. Battery life is the deal breaker. Does not last even half-day. All in all, I am not just saying what is right or wrong with this watch, but the overall experience.
I absolutely love this watch. Since it came out I've been wanting this specific model and it finally went on sale plus the payment option made it a no brainier

This is a very nice looking watch and if not horrible battery life i would leave them, however after testing them for a few days i came to conclusion that i won't be able to keep them.
I tried using this watches with iPhone.
1) Quickly my favorite mode became the custom mode, where i would leave only certain things needs for watch to last as long as possible. However after changing features, the watch changes the mode without telling you and then you screwed.
2) At first i tried using both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi mode and the battery would drain in just couple hours
3) I then disabled WiFi, as the phone suggested and tried using only with Bluetooth.
Using with built-in watch faces, the phone would last at most half a day. Once smartwatch goes below 30% it stops being a smart-watch and goes into extended mode, which is good if you are away from home and want to extend your battery life, but for any normal person who wants to use smart features, this is useless.
4) There are about 50 watch faces, but only 1 has seconds, which don't show up in the DIm mode.
The Facer App is great and it has nice watch faces and my own Design2 has seconds, but Facer restricts seconds in DIM mode as they say to save on battery life.
5) Using a Walk Mode to count steps with GPS turned on for 20 minutes, drained 10-15% of battery life.
If I don't want the GPS being turned on, then a valid question why do i need to pay $170 for the feature which i am afraid to use so that battery won't drain?!!
6) Another test of Bluetooth and Wifi and I lost 25% in 2 hours with watches only being in the dim mode. Comparing side-by-side with my old Sony Smartwatch3 which is still at 91% vs this new cool watch at 75% is making me nervous.
Should I know bring additional charger with me and check the battery life every half an hour?
That's not what i want.
I saw in other reviews that people were able to get thru the whole day, but in my opinion it is possible only in the extended mode, without any connection to the phone.
So yes, if you only want to count steps and check your BPM, this watches will probably last a full day.
But if you want to check text messages and emails and do even anything in the non-dim mode, the battery will drain on your eyes.
The last few days before returning the watches i tried only using them for basic needs and the watches hardly lasted for 8 hours.
My needs are 15 hours a day and the watch can't handle it.
Very unfortunate, because the watch is very nice looking with nice interface but not for the needs of an active person who needs them for more than 8 hours.

I have been using this watch regularly for about a month now. I have tried out all the features from the description so far and they all work very well.  I give great praises to this watch and would recommend it to anyone looking for a well rounded fully featured watch without the need for mobile calls, texts, etc. independent of having their phone on or near them. That said there are only two minor issues I have with the watch.  First is battery life with all the features enabled. (This is a common issue with smartwatches.)  The watch will last just about a full day.  I suspect that over the two to three years of expected use that the battery will degrade to the point where it works for about a half a day.  I have had this happen with my previous smartwatches and it ended up restricting usage to the point where I rarely wore it.  The other issue war that I experienced an instance of disablement.  This was fixed with a reboot of the watch by pressing down on the crown (main button) for about 10-15 seconds until it vibrated, while it was charging on the charger. Again, this watch is great.  I highly recommend it if you want a smartwatch with these features in 2020.  It's arguably the best Android Wear watch for value as of this writing.  I just have a hard time giving any "smartwatch" that's out there today a 5 star rating as the tech used in these devices isn't quite mature enough yet to grant one yet.

I'm on a mission to try out a couple different smart watches so I can pick a new daily driver. My first watch was the Fitbit Luxe (technically more of a fitness watch) and it had very little features, the app was garbage, and that fitness tracking wasn't that great which is the reason why I bought it. So I sent it back and bought the Gen 5 Carlyle. Pros:
- Uses Wear OS so you have access to a bunch of great apps
- Completely waterproof (the Fitbit had to be out into "water lock" if you wanted it to be waterproof)
- Pretty responsive once I de-cluttered it and got rid of some bloat ware
- Can reassign the hardware buttons to go to whatever app you want
- Layout is relatively easy to use Cons:
- Really really really bad battery life. If I use it normally throughout the day it's usually needs charged around the afternoon which sucks
- Heart rate monitor sucks. Have to have it in the perfect position on your wrist in order for it to work which means it's probably not gonna track your HR while you work out.
- Notifications show up in the notification center but I don't get actually notified with vibration or a tone most of the time. Sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't Conclusion:
If you can get it at a discounted price I think it's a great BUDGET option. There's a new generation for these watches but from what I've heard not much have changed unfortunately. It's better than the Fitbit Luxe by A LOT though. Gonna send it back and try out the Galaxy watch next.

This watch does everything, for a limited amount of time. It probably only has about an hour or two of actual usage time. Fortunately, it's a watch, so you aren't using it constantly. I really wanted to use this for sleep tracking, so usually I charge it before bed, and by the time I wake up it's at 75%. From there I go to school/work all day. Depending on the day, and how much time I charge it before I leave, it lasts until some time after 5pm. Basically I have to charge it once or twice a day most days - sometimes when I get home, and always before bed. That's the story of the awful battery. Besides the awful battery this watch does everything. I've gotten many compliments on the Google Pay functionality. That and the notifications are my favorite parts. The knob for scrolling feels very nice, as do the other two buttons. Can't really say anything bad about the watch. WearOS could use some work however, maybe some optimization to help with the battery life, but mostly just app support. I use Textra for texting, but Textra doesn't support WearOS, so if I want to text from my watch I have to change apps, which I'm not willing to do. For now, I can just reply to messages through notifications. It also seems like I should be able to open apps on my phone from all notifications, not just certain ones. At least I can be pretty certain that I will receive future updates, as the watch is cutting edge right now. Overall, this thing is awesome. Using it feels like something out of a sci-fi film. Would absolutely buy again.

I've had the phone for about 3 weeks now and love it! These are in no particular order. Hope this helps! Pros
1) Display is beautiful
2) Speed is very responsive
3) The watch bezel allow you to navigate the menu quickly
**4) Battery life. To get a day or 2 out of this watch certain features need to be checked and turned of. The heart rate sensor has pulsing green lights. When you 1st get this these are constantly taking a reading also killing the battery.
A) You have to turn the Heart-rate sensor Always-on setting OFF in Google Fit. This was not inuitive
B) Most of the time my GPS is Off unless I'm using the Map App
C) Set your battery settings to custom so you can control whats using your battery
*D) When you 1st get this the life of the battery sucks. after 4  or 5 charges it will balance out to 1 to 2 days of use before charging.
E) I have my brightness set to the highest at 5 and I don't see a significant drain on the battery. I don't really like the auto brightness feature. 5)  Love having Google Maps on my wrist!
6) Google assistant can answer questions and navigate the watch(sometimes).
7) Easily connects to the phone. I am personally using the Mate 10 Pro.
8) The Metal clasp one act as a stand and you can have the charging puck tucked in the middle. Cons: 1) There is a learning curve and its mostly the software
2) You have to update Android Wear and the play store out of the box.
3) Google Assistant will not navigate all watch features and menus but most.
4) Play store is limited but there is a mini YouTube app, compass, maps and fitness apps available
5) Speaker quality. Good for music. Static-y for phone calls. ( I still need to mess with these to see if I'm doing something wrong) but the few calls I made were horrendous yet they said I sounded fine on their end.
6) Hope the Android Wear ecosystem gets better.

Love this watch! It feels nice like a quality watch. I have received multiple complements when wearing it as it actually looks like a watch not some mini computer on your arm.
Fossil has been great with updates when I first opened the watch and set it up I had to update it a few times and it took a while but that just shows that fossil is keeping up support.
The battery life could be better. I wear it to work and I do 10-13 hour shifts by the time I hit 8-9 hours the watch is already is battery saver mode so I have to charge it every night. But it hasn’t died on me during a shift yet.
My only complaint is that when I switched to iPhone this watch caused a lot of issues with the iPhone. When it worked what it could do was limited but it was still usable. Most of the time I was having issues because it would disconnect from Bluetooth and wouldn’t want to reconnect this would also cause other Bluetooth devices to have issues connecting. I would have to turn Bluetooth off and on and forget the devices and re connect them. Most of the time that would work but sometimes I would have to restart the phone. I stopped using the watch.
Great smart watch for android horrible issues with iPhone.

The elephant in the room: battery life.
If I can get 16-18 hours, that's long enough to get it back on the charger when I go to bed. More is better but a watch must meet this minimum standard. This watch manages that and a little more, especially if I keep app usage to a minimum. I demand two things from a smartwatch: the time and discreet notifications for messages, emails, and calls on my phone. Weather at a glance is nice, too. I don't want to use my watch as a speakerphone or music player and I certainly don't want to have it giving me constant turn by turn prompts from Google Maps. Heart rate and step tracking are useful but I haven't worn a watch while sleeping since I was in the Army three decades ago so sleep tracking is lost on me. In terms of capabilities, this watch is overkill for me but it looks nice and the Prime Day price was too good to pass up. My only major gripe is the dangerously exposed glass bezel. It sits up above the body of the watch and is easily cracked (this is not my first Carlyle HR). I strongly recommend a TPU or silicone cover/bumper to protect the glass. All in all, it is a good replacement for my LG G Watch R, which died after several years of rugged and reliable service

As a software developer, I get great enjoyment out of this watch. It's sleep tracking and heart monitoring abilities are fantastic and I, someone who has only ever worn pajamas to bed, have been able to sleep with it on with zero issue. Battery life is a drain for me because I like to use all the features but, if you turn all that off you could definitely get two-days use. I'm excited to potentially take this camping and be able to leave the phone in the car! It's sleek design is handsome out of the box, and it's beauty is only slightly hidden by the plastic "suit of armor" case i bought for it. I don't know how resistant the screen is to scratches and cracks and I'm not keen to find out, but the touch screen has no issue with a screen cover. Just take the cover off if you have to hop on a video call or take a selfie! My last thoughts are that I wouldn't expect much in terms of quantity of apps. If you don't care about health tracking, or the watch's functionality, and are only interested in new apps, I wouldn't have FOMO if you don't have a Smartwatch, and would advise you wait a couple more years for more apps to enter the market.

Use it for last 4 months. Have very mixed feelings. From one hand it has many advantages, but disadvantages just kill customer experience. Support (does it exist?) is not responsive. Now a bit about pros and cons.
Advantages:
- nice looking. It is very subjective of course, but it is one of the best looking smart watches (for my taste)
- durable. By coincidence I was hitting or scratching different surfaces by this watch, they kept it well, screen is still like new
- fast charge. Comparing to Galaxy Active 2 this charges are least twice as fast
- different battery modes. One can easily switch between them and chose high performance or saving battery Ok things:
- battery life. Improved from gen 4 and similar to other rivals
- there are some apps. Not too many, but some are useful Disadvantages:
- Bluetooth connection. It sucks. Sometimes they are connected, sometimes they disconnect. When you try to switch it back, it is not enough (like manual says) just to tap on Bluetooth connection and then phone. Instead one has to switch off and on Bluetooth, sometimes several times. Sometimes you have to open app on phone and then it connects.
- no sleep tracking. They (producers) can’t make sleep tracking!!! 20$ watch have it but this don’t!
- GPS sucks. One of the main purposes I bought this watch was to be able to run without phone. This is almost impossible. If you are lucky GPS will connect after 15 minutes, if not - never without your phone, only when you are home and connected to a cell phone.
- APP on a phone. Piece of crap. Connection is not stable. Integration between watch and phone is weird - you update, it says it is updated, but steps count on watch and phone are different. Activities can upload for more than a day, although app says it is synced, what the hack? As a conclusion. I’d you like style and look of this watch and do not plan to use it for lots of sport activities - take them, you most probably will be very happy. If you like to use it for sports, sleep tracking - consider another model. Ps. I use them with my IPhone. Maybe Android would allow more, but Apple doesn’t allow much :(
Unfortunately I hate Apple Watch and it is problematic to find watches supported by iOS.

This is my 3rd Android/Google smartwatch, and the first one that I purchased brand new.
I've been using this watch for just a little over a month now and I'm very pleased with it as a replacement for my LG Urbane2. I never had a SIM card in the LG so battery life was never an issue with the larger battery it had.
I only upgraded mainly for 2 reasons, first the microphone died, and second the watch band was breaking. I purchased the LG "refurbished" for $100 and was really happy with it, but since the mic was bad and it was going to cost around$75 for a replacement band it was time to upgrade. The LG was purchased to replace the original Moto 360 I bought used because the battery was failing again. The original lasted over a year for me, the replacement fell just shy of a year. Plus it was an upgrad adding a speaker and the ability to use Google pay on the watch. I wear this watch daily and usually have at least 10% battery life left when I put it in the charger at night. Battery life in I  a custom mode with everything turned on except Ok Google detection. This watch so far is just superior to both of my previous smart-watches. My only apprehension buying was to he smaller battery capacity compared to what it replaced. However this makes the watch thinner on my wrist, and for me the size is great! I love that I can use any 22mm standard band on it and change it out easily. That was a big downfall of both of it's predecessors for me requiring special bands. I am by no means a heavy user of the watch. I have been wearing a watch for about 30 years now, I never could adjust to just using my phone.
This for me as an automotive technician is great because I don't have to take my gloves off or get grease all over my phone just to see who is calling or texting at that moment. For me the smart-watches are an extension of the phone, and it's great for getting notifications without having to keep the phone in my pocket.

Three weeks ago I purchased 2 highly rated Wear OS watches, the Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle and a Ticwatch Pro 4G LTE (to be paired with my Pixel phone). The Fossil was intended to be my daily driver, worn to my full time job as a teacher and also going on volunteer Fire/EMS calls during my work days. As an EMT there's one feature of this watch's 3100 chipset that I particularly like: you can get watch faces that have a moving sweep second hand even when the always on display is asleep or dimmed. This is something most smartwatches can't do and it's really important for taking patients' vital signs. Overall, I really like this watch. It's essentially my "dress" watch, as opposed to the larger Ticwatch Pro. The Fossil is relatively thin and looks good on my small-ish wrist. The included silicon band isn't great, though. It's a dust/ lint magnet. My use case is mostly for notifications. I don't use the activity tracker features much, other than the step counter and rarely the heart rate sensor. I do have the always on screen enabled as well as the lift to wake option, but not NFC. With those settings I usually end a16 hour day with about 33% battery left. I don't use sleep tracking and I charge it every night. The Fossil's swim rating makes me comfortable wearing it in wet environments. I am a bit concerned about screen protection, though. The glass is not protected by a bezel and it's apparently not Gorilla Glass, either. Fossil told me it's "alkali-aluminosilicate sheet glass commonly used in conumer electronics." That's what Gorilla Glass is, so this may be a competing company's product? There is a software glitch with this watch. There's an option to turn on Do Not Disturb when the watch is off your wrist. This does work. However, it doesn't turn Do Not Disturb off when you put the watch back on, so you miss notifications. I just turned this option off. In conclusion, the Fossil Gen 5 is a stylish smartwatch that will easily get you through the day with light/moderate use and the added benefit of always having a sweep second hand visible if you need that for healthcare or some other reason. Recommended.

One of the main things I was concerned about getting a Wear OS watch was batter life. So many reviewers of so many models complained that their watch would last the day. I use the custom settings to save on battery life, with a few things I don't need like GPS and always on display turned off. I do have NFC and the heart rate monitor turned on. The watch easily lasts the day. I put it on the charger at night while getting ready for bed, and it charges quickly, so I usually pull if off the charger at 90% to extend the battery's life. Even only charging to 90% and leaving it all night, it easily lasts the next day. I love the customizable buttons. I have the top one set to Google Pay, so paying for things is super quick and easy -- no scrolling through apps to get into Google Pay. The bottom button takes me straight to my workout timer. Before getting this, I hadn't worn a watch for years, since my phone can give me the time, and I preferred not having a bulky thing strapped to my wrist. This watch is thin enough that it doesn't bug me. The band was probably nicer than most, but I replaced it anyway (with a magnetic closure metal mesh one, which adjusts to literally any size and breathes well while working out.) One thing I love about both the original and replacement bands is that no tools are required to remove or install them. So you can get multiple bands and switch between them to match whatever occasion. The OS has been extremely stable. This morning was the first time I ever had to restart it in a month and half. (It was showing the time, but not unlocking for some reason.) I love that the watch face is customizable. I actually created my own face in Facer with my company logo and a nice clean design with just the elements I want on it. Finally, before getting a smart watch, I was a little skeptical about how much more convenient it would be to check messages and the time on a watch vs. a phone. I am no longer skeptical. It is so convenient.

Sorry, fans of the watch from that "other" company: REAL watches are ROUND.  This watch is round. I have to say, I love the style of this watch--it's genuine Fossil, and looks sharp.  I had to go with the leather band (whose dark brown color goes surprisingly well with the black watch), but I am looking at buying the steel watchband for it since I find those more comfortable.  I also own an LG G Watch R in rose gold that looks nice, but the hardware is a few years old now and it's not as snappy as it used to be.  But, it is still more than capable.  The Fossil is a nice change, and the black case is a nice alternative to the LG! What I like?  The buttons on the side do something, even the "stem" that can be rotated in one direction for notifications and in the other for settings.  And as I said, the style of it is high quality without looking pretentious (and it's not a ridiculous "rounded square").  There are plenty of Fossil-designed watch faces that can be installed and customized.  (I like using Facer, but their app has gotten bloated and drags down the OS on any watch I have tried it on.)  Apps are snappy.  I don't use the voice features, but it's interesting that is now has a tiny speaker. What I don't like?  Battery life is not good.  Unless I need to use this a lot more to somehow "calibrate" the battery and the OS, I can't see this lasting throughout a day.  Although I admit that I was playing with the watch quite a bit right after I got it.  Still, after 20-30 minutes, I don't expect battery life to have dipped into the sub-90% range.  Also, the charging pad is rather small.  The LG has a nice, large magnetic base that it sits within.  This is just a small magnetic charging pad that the Fossil perches on top of. It's a keeper, though! I'm glad I purchased this one on sale, and am looking forward to receiving the steel watch band for it.

So I have been looking for a good Android alternative.  Decided to take a chance on the Fossil after considering it with the Armani 3.  Now I exercise daily, walking and every 4 days add 30 - 40 minutes of weightlifting.  I also own a Series 5 Watch and a couple of Garmins and never have a problem getting all day from Apple or multiple days with Garmin.  So the first day with Fossil I put it on at 6:30AM.  Lifted weights first for 34 minutes then went out for a 4.2 mile walk.  When I finished the walk I noticed the battery life was down to 57%.  So I went in to notifications and turned off everything but two.  Left the AOD on (can only dumb it down so much).  At 2:30 PM the watch was completely dead.  Put it on the charger for the rest of the day.  Day two I went in and customized the battery settings and turned off as much as I could.  Put it back on the charger to get it back to 100% before walking.  So back on the wrist at 6:45am, 5 minute drive to where I was walking.  Did a 5.4 mile walk, just under 90 minutes.  Checked the battery again  and noticed the watch was down to 53%.  Day two actually lasted a little longer.  Watch completely shutdown at 4:15 PM.  So I wanted to see how it would do with music and exercise so I added a Playlist and setup my Jaybird Vistas on the watch for day three.  Day 3 made sure battery was at 100% before the short drive for my walk and put it on at 6:50AM.  Day 3 walked 4.5 miles 78 minutes with music and GPS.  Checked the battery at the end which was down to 41%.  Watch was completely drained at11:50AM.  I could probably go into settings and make some changes to probably extend this for a couple of hours, but it seems kind of pointless because now I have a Smartwatch not doing anything.  Short battery life seems to be kind of common with Android watches right now.  I am not really sure if this is due to Wear OS not being optimized yet or if it is the hardware that vendors are using.  So all day for me would typically be from around 5:00AM to 10:00PM at night. Even if I could get the Fossil to the Evening hours I would consider keeping it, but routinely completely dead in the afternoon has me returning this.  Really hoping that Google takes the Smartwatch business seriously this year and comes out with something nice.

Delivery and package

-Closed package (new), good but it was not tighten to the amazon box. After +4 days of use,
SmartWatch, first impressions:

Yes, by all accounts it should work with iPhone, even if with limited functionality, but it doesn't work consistently.  I keep the app open in the background, but it still loses sync multiple times throughout the day and I have to turn bluetooth off on the watch and back on before it finally syncs back up.  And you have to sync it with the app and the phone, so you'll see 2 entries of the watch connected in your bluetooth settings.  If you don't sync it with the phone also, you don't get notifications and stuff.  I never could get the heart rate monitor working.  Features seem to be not supported on iOS.  So I do not recommend this for iPhone. However, I gave it to my wife to try on her Android and it worked great for her.  Kept track of her steps, heart rate, sleep... everything I wanted the watch to do worked for her.  The watch itself is gorgeous, the screen is great, the band is a soft rubber that feels good on the wrist (I also got a metal band to swap out when I want to look fancy).  I really loved this watch and wished it would have worked on my iPhone better.  That's not entirely Fossil and WearOS's fault.  Apple purposefully locks down their stuff to make it as hard on 3rd party companies to offer quality products that work on iOS as possible so users are forced to buy Apple products, as I have been forced to buy an Apple Watch instead in order to get full functionality with my iPhone.  If you have Android, I can't recommend this watch enough.  If you have Apple, try elsewhere.

Pros:
- Great battery life. My screen is not always on, only wakes up when I tilt the watch. This way I can easily get 1.5-2 days per charging.
- Nice look and feel. Not too big. The leather bands give it a really nice look. Received many compliments that it looks nice and is similar to a real watch.
- Really good screen size and resolution. The pictures in IMs, search results, etc. are very detailed and useful even on such a small screen.
- Very good synchronization with the phone. The alerts appear on the phone and watch almost the same time. The dismissed notifications also disappear on the phone.
- A lot of good apps Cons:
- The touchscreen is very fragile. I scratched it on the second day of wearing it. It's really frustrating, because I was wearing a smart fitness watch for the past 4 years, which never got sratched. So beware: get a protective foil, glass or case over the screen.
- Charging is very difficult. The charging pad snaps to the back of the clock, but 9 times out of 10 it doesn't start charging. Most days I need to fiddle with it for 5-10 minutes until it finally starts to charge. Even then, sometimes it stops charging around 80%.
- The big middle button sticks out and I always accidentally long press it, starting the Google Assistant voice command recognition. Sometimes I press even longer and accidentally switch off the clock (e.g.: during exercising).
- The system sounds/chimes are very poor quality. For example, the notification of the start of charging, or when an alarm goee off, the watch sounds like a mobile phone from the 90's. Definitely not like a nice smart watch like this should sound. This is probably the fault of WearOS and could be customized, but would be nice to have it out of the box.
- Sleep tracker is not included by default. Conclusion:
I'm using it for a bit less than a month and am really happy with the watch.
My wife has a series 3 Apple watch and this Fossil watch seems to be at the same level in speed and functionality. The Fossil's battery life seems to be a lot better. I also think that this watch can display more text on its screen than the series 3 Apple watch.
So if you can live with the cons listed above, I definitely recommend purchasing it.

I was on the fence wanting to buy the ticwatch pro 2020 given it's more innovative display and battery claims.  This went on sale significantly cheaper so is it a good smartwatch?  Yes it is. The Positive: The screen has excellent fidelity.  It's the most clearly handsome smartwatch.
Their is no real lag in the apps which was a frequent complaint on wear os devices.  Replying to messages sent via different apps via voice or text on the watch is nice. The Bad:  Wear OS has a very small catalog of apps.  Battery in extended mode only lasts a day and a half of moderate use.  Regular mode is good for about a day.  While in extended apps like the weather don't function.  You would just use it to check and reply to various notifications and check time. Note: If you don't normally wear a watch and we're looking at getting the metal banded version be aware you will most likely need to take links out and buy one of those hammer and push pin kits to take out the links. They run around 12 bucks on Amazon. Prior to buying this I was curious how this or even if this would work with my companies work profile on my phone.  There isn't much data on this on the internet.  My company chose not to approve the wear os app on their profile so some options are limited.  The Microsoft Teams app notifications that pop up when people message you do pop up on the watch.  You can respond to those messages with voice to text responses.  I was pretty pleased in at least that win. You will not be able to sync the companies calendar appointments etc though.  Hope that helps. Overall I like the watch.  I do find myself wishing it had some of the features (for batteries sake) of the newest ticwatch but do enjoy the look of this one more.

Had the watch for a long time. I use it as my daily watch. It's durable. I find myself banging it against door frames and other things pretty often, and it has no damage. It's actually waterproof. I've taken it swimming, and have taken it about 12ft deep in water, and never had any issues. The water did not activate the touchscreen, and the dials and buttons worked fine. The battery life is a bit disappointing. You need to pick and choose which settings you want on in order to have the watch last throughout the entire day. My biggest suggestion is to turn off any gesture controls, because they get accidentally activated so often that it kills your battery life. WearOS is the biggest problem with the watch. It's kinda buggy, the menus are annoying to go through, and the settings are lacking. For watch faces, I suggest finding an app that you can design your own, or download other custom made faces. I use Facer to make my own digital watchface. Notifications come in at the same time as your phone. There isn't any delay between your phone vibrating and your watch vibrating. However, sometimes the watch will disconnect from Bluetooth for no reason. It's not often, maybe once a month or so, but it's happened enough that I can bring it up in this review. Also the brightness settings are absolutely trash. You have the option of 1 through 5, 1 being the dimmest, 5 being the brightest, but unless you're only using the watch at night, you need to keep it on the brightest setting at all times. I also find it really hard to see in direct sunlight. Also to note: replace the watch strap it comes with. If you get sweaty, it starts to stink really bad.

...Well... this watch changed my mind. It would actually be 5 stars except for the fact sometimes my watch loses sync with my phone.  But that happens with my car and phone too so maybe it's my phone. Huh. (EDIT - changed it to five stars because it turns out it WAS my phone that was losing sync and not the watch.) Well anyways yeah I never thought smartwatches made any sense whatsoever, especially not at $300+. But then this bad boy went on sale for under $210 and I am one of those people who always misses phone calls, txts, and emails because I lay my phone down and forget about it. Yeah my life does not revolve around a phone. But with the coronavirus lockdown I needed to be instantly reachable for work since I'm working from home right now. Yet I hate carrying my phone around when I'm at home. So a small device that I can wear on my person that instantly lets me know when someone is trying to reach me AND i can txt and take phone calls on it?! PERFECT. And this bad boy IS perfect. Although when doing my research I kept reading how Samsung watches have so much better battery life, what Samsung watches *don't* have is Google assistant. And Samsung's speech-to-text is HORRIBLE. My wife's Note 9 cannot understand what I'm saying u-n-l-e-s-s I t-a-l-k s-l-o-w l-i-k-e I h-a-v-e s-p-e-c-i-a-l n-e-e-d-s, but my Huawei Mate SE *perfectly* translates my everyday speech to text - even when i've got loud music playing. And since I'm not trying to type on a tiny 1" screen, that only leaves me the option of buying a watch whose speech-to-text actually works or else I have to go find my phone again. Nah. So I bought this watch and after the first two days the battery life improved drastically (usually end with anywhere from 20% to 40% after a 16-hr day. Like right now it's after 10pm and I still have 48% left. Pro Tip: turn the screen off while watching TV.) And it understands my speech-to-text needs perfectly. Best of all, it has Google assistant so it seamlessly works with all my google stuff. Now my boss can call and I always pick up. I see emails immediately and can respond to the ones that actually need an immediate response, and same for txts. As for the health/heartbeat functions I'm not into all that, so never use them. All-in-all I am very happy with my smartwatch purchase, even though I am probably about to be laid off and can't afford it haha. Too late! I already love it so it stays.

I bought this specifically because I needed Wear OS integration. I have Type 1 Diabetes and wear an electronic device to continuously monitor my blood sugar, a Dexcom G6 CGM, and that only works with iOS or Wear OS. Otherwise, I might have chosen another watch, but this was one of the best of the Wear OS ones, although I considered a couple of MobvoiTicWatch watches. So far, the features I use and can comment on: - I can see my blood glucose measurements on my watch at all times, which is why I needed Wear OS. This is fantastic. It relies on Bluetooth between the watch and has been reliable unless I am separated by multiple concrete walls. - The message integration is nice and keeps me alerted, and when I have 2-factor authentication for a site, I get the code on my watch, which is way more convenient than reaching for the phone. It is convenient to get my messages on the watch, and usually just swipe them away, or if interested, respond. It does transcribe verbal messages well. - I have taken calls on my watch, which is nice but can also be surprising if unexpected - I use the heart rate monitoring for my rowing and running workouts, which integrates with Google Fit. I'm not obsessed about the accuracy but the number lines up with my other heart rate monitor, a Scosche Rhythm 24. I use third-party apps to synchronize my Polar Beat and Withings BF Scale with Google Fit. - Throughout the day I use Google Assistant, the countdown timers, the stopwatch, the UV Index app, Google Breathe (this is nice) - I am enjoying sleep tracking to get a sense of how many hours of rest I am getting. (Sleep was added later in 9/2020, as part of a Wellness App update). Quibbles - The usual is the battery, but I generally get a full day with moderately active use, although if I'm very busy, I charge it while wearing one of my older watches. Charging is very fast. - Occasionally, I need to swipe twice if it doesn't recognize it, but that could be me. - On a few occasions, Google Assistant didn't respond, so I either turned it off then on or simply pressed the assistant icon and spoke then.

Update 9/6/20: after a major update, fossil now includes a wellness app that can do a lot of things that the watch was missing when it first came out – now it is a much more useful and versatile watch and I am bumping it up to four out of five stars. It still could use a bit better battery life, but it has gotten a bit better after the update.
------------
I bought this watch because it has been consistently touted as the best smartwatch outside the Samsung/Apple ecosystems. If it is, having had a Galaxy watch, I can say that does not bode well for any brands besides the duopoly. That being said, it's a decent watch, just that you're really paying for brand on this one. As a lot of others have said, the battery life leaves something to be desired - however, coming from older Galaxy watches a day and a half to two days is what I'm used to. I was thinking if I switched from the anemic Tizen ecosystem to Wear OS I'd have a plethora of things to run on my watch, but the Wear OS app store is as anemic as any of the other proprietary ones, though that's not on Fossil. The controls are decent and the ability to program the side buttons is nice. The watch strap and back don't bother me, which is usually an issue so if you have sensitive skin, this doesn't bother a guy that can't wear surgical steel for the minute amount of nickel in it. I do really like that the straps are interchangeable, I have a few straps I've used with the watch so definitely a plus. The voice functions and speaker are okay. As long as you're not out in traffic or on a loud construction site you can hear what's coming out of it. Good enough for "can you pick up some bread while you're at the store" conversations and using Assistant, not so much anything else. And it's especially annoying to bump the crown, which is both a button and a knob, and hear my watch say I'm sorry I didn't hear you and find out that assistant has been sitting on. All in all, it's an okay watch. I'd definitely pay $120 for it, but not the $233 it was at when I bought it. Wear OS still has some maturing to do as a platform if it wants to play alongside the S/A duopoly because they really do have everyone beat.

The watch had functioned normally after I purchased it, but three months later, it stopped working entirely. Running its battery flat and connecting the adapter clearly indicated that it could charge as the watch would flash a charging indicator, but it would not do anything else and would soon stop even that. I had not subjected the watch to any possibly damaging situations. For instance, I never got it wet even though it's water resistant, nor did I subject it to shocks. The failure appears to be a quality assurance problem, although the specific cause in my case remains unknown. I reported this issue to the manufacturer, which covered the repair as it was still under warranty (one year). This process took a month or so, and it seems they replaced most or all of the components (the serial number has changed). The replacement watch has arrived very recently and is functioning well so far. If it experiences any problems, I will update this review.
This paragraph is about the software used by Fossil, Wear OS by Google, but is not specific to this particular watch. The operating system has several significant defects. The first is that, although it has the ability to use WiFi networks, it frequently decides that it's just not going to. The settings for WiFi are off and automatic, and automatic mode frequently means that it thinks it doesn't need to be connected right now. This meant that apps that used WiFi would either take several seconds to connect or would experience a large delay before informing me that no network was available. WiFi isn't needed if the watch is being used for time, notifications from a phone, or fitness tracking, but it would be for most complex apps. There used to be a developer setting that would prevent the automatic system disabling WiFi, but it has been removed. This is serious, as development virtually requires WiFi to synchronize data between the development computer and the test device, which is frequently broken. Similarly, connection to a paired phone over Bluetooth was spotty, and when it wasn't connected, it showed a notification about that often. I didn't use many features requiring a stable connection, but the constant notification was irritating. If you want a smartwatch in order to run complex applications, this platform will likely frustrate you, since most important functionality requires a network connection. For example, you can use dictation to type, but only if you're online. Otherwise you can try to type on a full QWERTY keyboard displayed on a watch screen, which is difficult. There are two programmable buttons, which are nice, but Wear Os only lets you use those buttons to launch applications. If you want a fast launch, that's great, but the system also puts the most recent three apps launched on the home screen so it's already easy. You can't map those buttons to specific features inside apps or to simulated key presses. If you use a degoogled AOSP-based Android, this watch won't work with it, or at all. It won't set itself up without the Wear OS app, and if you sideload that, it will complain and exit on startup. You have to install the app on an IOS or normal Android device for it to work, though a Google account isn't required. If you don't know what I just said, the situation probably doesn't apply to you.
When functioning, this watch ran as expected. Battery life was about two days when not used intensively and with power-intensive features like always-on screen disabled, but would fall behind if called upon to do other tasks. If you intend to use a Wear OS watch, expect to charge it every day. Audio quality is surprisingly good for such a small speaker, with loud sound output possible. Location from the GPS/GLONASS chip was generally accurate but took a long time to initialize and dramatically affected battery life.
In conclusion, proceed with caution only if you understand and accept the limits. One anecdote doesn't constitute a study on resilience, but there may be problems with the hardware. Meanwhile, the software has limits which cannot be circumvented. If you don't need compatibility with Wear OS apps, you may not want to use this. If you are developing wearable apps, you have Samsung's Tizen and Apple's Watch OS as alternative platforms.

The watch looks really nice in person and very classy on the wrist. The first day I wore it I received a random compliment from a bank teller who had no idea it was a even a smartwatch until I told her. So I definitely give it 5 stars for appearance, especially with all the cool watch faces you can choose from, download, or even custom make using 3rd party apps! Unfortunately, the native Google Fit app doesn't have the capabilities to monitor sleep tracking so you'll need to download and integrate a 3rd party app (such as 'Sleep As Android'). This was slightly inconvenient, but at least it works once you set it up and Google has done a good job of making it easy to integrate many 3rd party apps into Google Fit. However, it should be noted that while your watch can help capture your sleep data, you still won't be able to access your sleep data on the Google Fit app on your watch. Instead, that data will only be made visible on the Google Fit app on your phone. This is another slight inconvenience which is why I only gave the sleep tracking capabilities 3 stars at the end of the day. The battery life is easily good enough to last you the entire day and even longer if you use the battery saving features and don't use it for making calls, playing music and other things that obviously require additional battery life. I personally like to utilize a lot of the watch features, including wearing it overnight for sleep tracking, so I have to designate some time each day to recharge it. Thankfully, the watch recharges extremely fast (20 minutes or less) so I gave it 5 stars for battery life. The watch uses Google Wear OS as the native mobile app which is very easy and straightforward to use. You're able to change the watch settings, watch faces, connect accounts, and basically all the standard administrative tasks can be done within the app. Plus I have a Google Pixel phone so I'm not sure if that makes it any easier. I decided to give it 5 stars since the app basically does what I'd expect it to do with a clean interface. Overall, I gave the watch 4 stars just because of its inability to do certain things out the box without 3rd party apps. However, if you're willing to take the time to set it up you'll be able to customize it the way you want. Besides that, the smartwatch looks like a classy timepiece that will get attention. It also charges fast and has all the bells & whistles of any other smartwatch on the market. For the price I'd say this Fossil watch is a great option!

So far after a week I can say this watch is a joy to use.  This is a big upgrade on my old Fossil Sport.  The addition of speaker and better all day heart rate detection was a big plus for me.  The additional ram also really helps the processor shine and it moves through menus much faster now.  Buttons also have a nicer feel the rotary dial middle button moves much smoother.  Fossil did a great job of upgrading this product without the expense of the battery.  I am getting probably a little more over a days charge with the AOD display on and all features on.  It has other options to extend the battery to a week and balance battery life.  Not to mention the screen is larger and the weight of the watch is still very comfortable for a middle aged man to carry.  I have not tried swimming with this watch like i did on my old sport but that watch handled normal swimming like a champ so I expect this will too.  If only Wear O.S had good swim tracking apps. Pros For Me:
- Peppy performance very little to no lag in menu transitions
- Exceptional battery life (there are tricks to extend your battery performance) you should have no trouble making a full active day on one charge.
- Improved heart rate tracking with Caridiogram pre installed.  The watch checks my heart rate every 5 minutes and still makes a full day charge
- Easy to install your favorite watchband and inexpensive protective bumpers and screen covers can be found if your tough on your watch like I am.
- Fossil kept the same charger! So if your upgrading like me your old chargers still work and you can keep a spare in the car or office.  Thank you fossil!  Spare chargers are also inexpensive and easy to find for your travel needs.
- Great watch faces - Fossil packs  a good selection but Wear O.S in general gives you a ton of options that you can change up for mood and occasions. Cons:
- Wear O.S is still wear o.s but it has come a long way to be more smart watch competitive.
- The Style of this watch is simplistic and not very flashy so it will not standout if that is what you are looking for
- I wish fossil would make a watch with a rotating ring around the face like some of the Samsung watches.  I would buy that watch in a heartbeat!
- I think it does sleep tracking but since you need to charge the watch at night you cant really use this feature.
- No cellular options.  I had this on my old LG smart watches and while I did not use it often it would be nice if it was a option for when you cant be near your phone.

Slow process getting to the point where forking over the dough for a Wear OS watch looked appealing. My goal: tight, trouble free integration with Google Fit, which is my favorite app for collecting and visualizing exercise, weight, and similar data.
Other solutions I tried had spotty data syncing (MiFit) or overwrote the weight data from my smart scale (VeryFitPro).
Pleased to report that using Fossil Gen 5 to track steps and walks and other exercise events sends data promptly and reliably to Google Fit both on the watch and on my phone. Weight data from my Wyze scale syncs well to Fit and nothing overwrites it.
Fossil's sleep tracker syncs fine w/Fit, but isn't all that accurate at detecting when I'm asleep and when awake... so, I'm not sure what that's worth. Sleep tracking was not a priority anyway.
Battery life is a challenge, but not bad once you get the watch customized and quit fiddling with it. The process of navigating a lot and installing apps, and other customizing eats up battery quicker than anything else. I can get 24 hours easy now and probably 2 days if I tried a little.
The black silicon band looks cool in flat black but it's a magnet for tiny bits of skin and anything else that isn't flat black.... so looks dirty most of the time. I'll be replacing that soon. It is quite comfortable though.
I have small bones, so I wear it on second to the last hole. The watch itself is a wee bit bulky but not bad. Here's to hoping that in the future the battery life doubles while the watch gets thinner. :-)  ... chances are good, eventually.
---
Update 4/14/22
It's been just over a year. The watch has held up pretty well, but I have to knock a star off, maybe two. The watch has an intermittent problem where it rapidly drains its battery for no apparent reason. In support forums, etc., others report similar problems. Theories range from wifi connection to 'just a glitch, reset the watch and you'll be fine.' The random fast drain is very fast. This morning I took it off the charger at 7:30 AM. It had about 10% battery left at noon. Usually, after restarting watcha and recharging, it's normal again for a period. Usually weeks, but sometimes only a few days.
Recently the fast drain thing happened when I was at an event, and it was a bummer to go to do a tracked walk and discover there wasn't enough power left (early afternoon).
Battery is a struggle even when it's not acting up. It makes it through day, excluding any sleep cycle. That is, there is not enough battery to get through 24 hrs. More like 16 or 18.  And with the margin so tight, if you turn on an activity that enables GPS and heart rate checking (usually I don't have that turned and don't have heart rate turned on either), then forget to turn it off when you're done...  Battery is going to be zapped way before bedtime.
So, I'm shopping for something better. Given the demands of Wear OS, you have to plan to spend more than $300 (probably a lot more) to get a battery life that will forgive imperfect power management and still get you through 24 hours. Given how I actually used the watch over the last year, it doesn't look like Wear OS and Google Fit are worth it. 99% of the features I actually use are available on fitness watches like Garmin's line with triple or quadruple the battery life. I will probably wave goodbye soon to both Wear OS and Google Fit until the tech catches up with practical realities and practical pricing.

As far as smartwatches go, this is undoubtedly the best one to buy in terms of cost/performance. I'll break down the various parts of the watch, what works, and what doesn't, and add final thoughts below. I'll be comparing this at some points to the TicWatch 2020, as it is one of the closest competitors. Case:
The case is made of lightweight metal, and the lugs for the band are very sturdy as well. The fact that the charge contacts are rings and not points is also a plus. Face & Bezel:
The face is clear, and easy to read, but here's where I'll be deducting some points: First, the face and screen are not exactly honest, as there is a 4mm dead ring between the bezel and true screen. I like a watch with a nice big face, and was hoping this would compare to the Ticwatch, but sadly, it does not. The lack of a raised bezel is also a bad thing, as this makes the addition of a screen protector necessary. Power:
Fortunately, this watch supports fast charging, compared to the Ticwatch, which must be charged specifically at 5v/1a, or it will burn out. Battery life is acceptable, so long as you treat this more as a watch... Any heavy usage will mean running out of power before your day is over. The power saver mode means it doesn't turn into a complete paperweight, but a second TFT screen would be appreciated so you could still do things like step counting, as is available on the Ticwatch 2020. Waterproofing:
The full swimmability is greatly appreciated, since for the money the last thing you want is to lose this to a fall off the dock, or getting pushed into the pool. Band:
The band is OK, but not very good. Switch to a multilink metal band instead for better ventilation and ease of cleaning. I recommend this one, or similar: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07GZC81MP/ Controls:
The two programmable buttons, and center crown are the most usable set of manual controls, hands down. I never get tired of using the crown to scroll through menus. This is far better than any two-button setup. Storage:
The fact that you have almost 6gb to install apps is far and away top of the line, with most other competitors offering barely 1.5gb Speed:
The Snapdragon 3100 makes WearOS function smoothly, with no noticeable lag when operating menus, streaming music, using your phone as a periscope or remote camera, and even playing video. The low power cores mean ambient mode does not flicker, even with a full color screen. Sensors:
The heart rate sensor seems to be accurate, and off-body detection works. Tap and Pay works as expected. Features I'd like to see in a future version:
Bigger screen that is truly what size it claims to be, hopefully as big as the Ticwatch screen.
Dual screen (like the Ticwatch) for low power mode.
Raised bezel, for protection without the need for a screen protector.
Left Handed Mode Overall, this is one of the best options out there, with the only major issues being the false screen size, and lack of a raised bezel. If you want a smaller screen, this watch will meet your needs nicely.

I spent a lot of time researching this watch. ?? The reviews on the battery life made me iffy about buying it but I haven't had an issue with that. It's between 50-70% (depending on the watch face I use) by the time I get home (10?ish hour day). Took it off the charger at 6:30a today. It's 8:23p and has 33% charge. There's all these different battery settings you can use to extend the life. I definitely had to finagle the bagel when I first got it because if I hadn't, by the end of this review it would have been dead already. I had a Galaxy Active. I wanted my watch to make noise and Galaxy did not. The vibration isn't what I wanted either. I do a lot of moving at work and don't always hear/feel my phone. This watch is loud and clear. The vibration is very noticeable. I only used the phone on the watch 3 times. It wasn't terrible. The conversations were short though. Most times I'm not in a setting where being Inspector Gadget is appropriate. I didn't like that the band is so big. I tried purchasing a 20mm band and they don't fit. I thought maybe that would solve the issue. I guess since I have average size womens' wrists, maybe I should have gotten the Juliana? But that's not what I wanted ??????? Anyway, I made an extra hole. That was a little tough, too. Which is good- the band does not tear/rip/puncture easily. ???? Someone said there aren't a lot of watch faces to choose from. I use Facer and I've found plenty free faces that I like, so I guess it's a personal preference. ??????? I bought this fancy bumper (because it was the only one I could find that wasn't that weird plastic that turns brown after some months and that also doesn't impact my being able to use/see the screen) and a separate set of plastic screen protectors for preservation. I don't use it for the sleep tracking. I take it off at night to charge. I don't use the GPS tracking. I don't like to keep my location on any device. Um..in my sleep apparently I took 70 steps, so either I sleep walk or it's really sensitive to movement. ?? The heart monitor seems fairly accurate (in comparison to my Galaxy). I like the Galaxy app better than the WearOS app. I feel it could definitely be better, give more options- something. It's very minimal. Comes with a charging cord and...that's it (other than the paperwork) ?? There's not 2 bands, like with the Galaxy. I'm happy over all though. ???? July 2021 Update: I haven't had ANY issues with my watch. I thought I may have an issue due to the physicality of my job, but nope! They've done an update on the WearOS app and I'm glad. It isn't 100% better, but it is 54.96% better than it was. ?? Everything is copastetic.

I've had this for a few weeks now, and I'll say that I'm overall happy with my purchase. For some background, I'm a Pixel owner who was looking for something that would feel seamless with the most recent Android operating system. I also wanted something that looked like a watch rather than a fitness band, as well as something that had GPS built in to track my bike rides. Pros:
* Well-built physical quality - I've worn it every day since it came, and it has been both comfortable and resilient. Granted, I work from home currently, so we'll see how it hold up when I'm back to a daily commute to the office.
* Good variety of features - it has bluetooth, wifi, GPS, and NFC. It has lots of apps to add if you like, as well as lots of watch face options. For the price, it's got a robust feature set that you can tailor to whatever you need.
* Good Android integration - one of the main reasons I got it. It's been nice to have it automatically feed my step counts and GPS into other apps
* Google Pay and Google Assistant integration - Pay has been great, and I've started using it to pay whenever I end up buying something in person. I haven't really used assistant all that often, but largely because I have Google Home Minis throughout the house and I don't leave much. I'm hopeful that I can use assistant a bit more down the road
* Always on display - I like that it still feels like a watch. I can look at my wrist to see the time
* Swappable bands - I got a second band (leather) from Fossil, and it's easy to swap to fit my mood. Cons:
* Terrible setup UX - took me forever. I had to restart and reinstall several apps in order to just get it to recognize my phone.
* Battery life - just isn't that great if you wear it all day with Bluetooth, Wifi, and notifications all day
* Battery saving modes - while I understand why it does it, I wish it wouldn't turn off bluetooth randomly to save battery. I suddenly realize I've missed messages because of the switch
* Weird connectivity overall - I've had a lot of dropped connectivity between this and my phone. I feel like it may have to do with connecting my phone to my computer, however, so I'm still troubleshooting
* Charger feels cheap
* I wish they sent something to remove links. I have very large hands/forearms, and it was big on me, so I'd imagine I'm not the only one in this boat. I ended up going ot the Fossil store, and they were incredibly nice and accommodating. They helped me get the fit just-right. Still, would be nice to have better instructions to do it myself Overall, this felt like, and still feels like, the best option on the market for a Pixel owner. It does everything I needed it to do, despite some quirks. If they could bring in some minor improvements, I feel like it would knock it out of the park.
I bought it for a friend as a gift, and he loves it.

Overall, definitely a great buy from what I consider a great company, over the years I've had many different fossil watches. This smart watch has been great only downfall is the charger doesn’t always connect to your watch to charge. Since the watch was gifted to me I've purchased 2 more chargers since 2021 with other smart watch companies I didn't have to buy a new charger. Sometimes the sleep tracker is a bit off but other than that, it's great!

My husband’s first smart watch. Bought so i could text him at work and he could at lear see it but he can text back on the watch. So has a keyboard. He does get sms notifications and even pics when i send one.  He really loves it. Battery life has been good. He mostly wears it for work. After 8 hours at work with alot of movement he has about 75 percent left. He thought it was just another watch when he opened it. I had to tell him it was a smart watch. He loves the leather band as well. Fossil has been a great brand so far.

It has been almost two years since I started wearing this and I thought I would come back and give a last update. At this point I wear this some of the time. It went from the watch I used most to this. Main reason for this was the battery hassle. You have to turn the display off and can't even use shake to activate to get a full day of use out of it. And I can't really be bothered having to charge it every day. I've switched mostly to a Skagen hybrid smart watch. I can't make calls using it but I don't really need it for that anyway.
All that aside, I do still like this fossil watch. The functions are incredibly useful, there's lots of space left to get apps, and it has lost nothing of it's functions. I started out rating this quite highly because my initial impression is that it is a great watch. This can change and I will come back to update this if it turns out to be poor.
Set up. Oh this was hard at first but deep breath, it can be done with minimal fuss and a time travel device. Dont pair your phone using Bluetooth until the prompt tells you to do it. Download wear os while this thing starts up. Allow locations in your phone settings then follow the wear os directions while your phone is next to the watch. It will set up but your phone has a Bluetooth pass code to connect. If it fails it's because your phone has already connected so you need to factory restore the watch and restart your phone.
Apps. Great connectivity from a Google phone as it lets you connect to all the apps from your account with minimal fuss. Download for Facebook messenger took a little while but nothing bad.
Battery seems to drop off very quick with extended use and download for apps. There is a battery customization mode to let you use it as little as possible to make the battery last. Also you can turn the display always on mode to off and save more power. Initially it was draining quickly so I will come back and let you know how it goes.
Appearance very nice but I'm afraid of that large display and have already bought screen protectors. Totally recommending this if you get this watch. The screen is huge and it is sensetive too. You can swipe easily and it doesn't appear to lag. This means it's expensive to replace so don't take a risk with it. And I will be back to update. Update... I'm discovering what some of the other reviewers said about the battery. On normal use mode it wouldn't last a day before you have to recharge it. So I'm taking it down to 4 stars because of that. This doesn't mean it's bad. It means you must go to the battery options and set it to extended use. I can tell you I left the house this morning at  7 am with the battery at 100%, returning home at 4.30pm and it's at 77%. This is with extended use settings and throughout the day very minimal use of the watch. Turning it on to check the time, pestering the wifey with a few nuisance texts, glancing at the news headlines because I was bored at work. That sort of thing.
For me this isn't perfect but it's not terrible either. I don't mind charging at the end of the day.
One other thing I noticed is that you must swipe from the sides. It might feel unresponsive to touch gestures but it really isn't. You just have to start at the side. Also tried making a phone call with the watch. I had to footer about with the settings a bit to get it to work but once it was set up correctly, the call quality was fine. I could hear the other person well and the call on the other end was working great, too.
Also tried speech to text and as per usual for Scottish folk, that doesn't always work out too well. Can't blame the watch for that. A sort of update to the update... Ok I get it now. I had an initial impression followed by the first part of a learning curve. That's my mistake.  This is the first smart watch I have used and my reaction was to treat it like a normal watch but one that does stuff. It's not quite that. It's a device that comes with a learning curve. You have to be patient with it and learn how to use it, what to do, how to experiment with it, and what not to do. One week in and I'm finding that out for myself by downloading new apps, and discarding others, changing settings and learning new functions.. So far my Impression is net positive. I'm happy with this and look forward to using it going forward. Update... I dont really need to charge this every day but find myself doing so anyway. If you want to keep a decent charge of 80 percent or so then you need to charge each day. But that's not a hassle because it charges quickly.
 Loving some of the apps for this. Fotmob has all the soccer scores I want and it will ring on my watch to let me know when my team are tragically losing once again.
There appears to be a distance I can remain close to my phone to have all the functions work properly. I've noticed indoors it appears to be about fifteen feet or so. I'm happy with that. Still very happy with the watch. Update. Last one I think. Changed it from a four to a three. I like it, but made a discovery that made me like it a little less. I took it off for the weekend, with the whole thing set to basically off. I didn't touch it and the watch wasn't doing anything for two whole days. When I took it off the charge was about 80 percent and when I picked it up again it was about 16 percent.
That's just daft. The battery ran down doing nothing.
Ugh.

I've been patiently waiting for years, for the perfect smart watch that would "check all the boxes," and the Fossil Gen 5 comes pretty close.  Here's my honest review. THE FACE
When I opened the box, the watch face was smaller than I expected, and I was disappointed to see that a black circle of non-active margin surrounds that actual display, making the real display even smaller than the smaller-than-expected watch face. But I've survived a week with it. Also, I don't know that other watches out there have a larger display. This was just my reaction to it. FONT SIZE
Next, I noticed just how small the type/font is on the screen for most notifications. Given my age and eye sight, the tiny print was near impossible to read. Fortunately, there is an accessibility setting to slightly increase the font size, though not much. BUILD QUALITY
The watch itself is built well, and it seems solid. The stainless steel band seems light weight, but does a good job. As a whole, it does not feel like a toy. It feels like a mid-range watch. CHARGING CORD
The charging cord, however, feels like a cheap piece of plastic and wire. It does not feel like a brand-name item, but rather, it feels like a replacement cord you would find on a rack for $1. The charging wire does not come with a charging block. Instead, you have to plug the USB-A end of it into a computer or other USB outlet. Also, the charging wire is incredibly short. Way too short.
