I don't think it's even 3 feet. It would be fine if it were plugged into my computer, but it's not at all long enough to have on your nightstand, even if an outlet us nearby on the wall. Lastly, the charging cord is magnetic and snaps onto the back. Two small pins then make contact with the case to charge. (It is not wireless.) HOWEVER, it's a relatively loose fit and does not have that satisfying snap connection that you expect. So you connect it, and set your watch down and just HOPE that it stays connected. I would prefer a connection that snaps, has a strong magnet, and you can feel confident in the connection. APPS
I am incredibly disappointed in the lack of apps for this smart watch, and for Wear OS in general. You would think that the company that makes Wear OS (Google) would make apps for it's most popular products like Gmail... but no, there is no Gmail app. There's no Google Voice app. etc. NOTIFICATIONS
While there aren't many apps to use, the notifications do work well. When your phone would normally beep or vibrate, so too does your watch. It shows me notifications for incoming Email, Google Voice messages, and even notifications from other apps. That's nice. For the messages, you can often reply back to the person, by using either the microphone or smart reply. That's nice. A big downside of the notifications system, however, is that there's no way to go back and look at previous or old notifications. So if grandma sent an email to me 20 minutes ago, and I already swiped away the notification, I cannot go back to it. NFC
I waited for a watch that has NFC for mobile payments / Google Pay. This watch does it, but so far I have not used it. I have my credit card all set up, but the first time I was at a store, I could not get the watch to do it, and I had to resort to my phone. This may be user error on my part. Hopefully I can learn to just quickly use my watch. GOOGLE FIT
For tracking fitness, I like that the watch is counting my steps, and that I can see my overall accomplishments for the day. I can use the watch to start a new activity (like running) but in that process, the crown does not function to scroll the list of activities. So you have to use your finger on the small screen. PHONE CALLS
I also waited for a watch that has a speaker and mic. So far I have only accepted one call on my watch. I guess it was okay. Unfortunately people just don't make calls these days so it's not something I've used much. SPEAKER / MUSIC / MEDIA
I have not been able to play music directly on the watch and out of the watch's speaker. I've also not played music from the watch and to headphones. So I cannot say those things work or don't. When you are using Spotify or Google Play, you can use the watch to skip forward and back on tracks, and play/pause, and adjust volume. I've used the watch to control music playing across the room on my Google Home; the stream was coming from the network and not from the watch. FINAL RULING
This watch normally sells for $295 and I bought it on sale for $205. When I first opened the package and played with it for about 30 minutes, my gut told me to send it back. But I decided to give it some time and extra chances. During the past week I have learned to appreciate the heart rate monitor and step counting aspect of the watch. I suppose I could say I like the notifications, too, though I am not too sure how much that helps my life versus the identical notifications on my phone! I admit to being a Google Fanboy with the latest Google products, and at the same time I am incredibly jealous that it SEEMS those with Apple Watches can do far more with their watch/phone combo. I could be wrong, but I bet they have better access to their email, messages, etc, via their watches. Is the Fossil Gen 5 worth $205, probably. Would I recommend it for $295? No way. Do I hope a future Wear OS has better features that can compete with Apple, and would I pay extra for that? Absolutely.

As you can tell, this is a quick summary of my experience using this watch with an IPhone, but a lot of the issues would be present no matter what device you have. It should also be noted I have the iPhone XR, which still functions great but is a couple years old now.
To start off, it was a rocky setup. I downloaded the “wearOS” app and the google fit app like it requires, and got everything set up. It was very glitchy and many of the features flat out didn’t work and it couldn’t stay connected. But once I factory reset the watch and went over the setup again, it seemed to work much better.
It also seems to work better when you keep the “wearOS” app open on the background. That probably sounds like it should be obvious but since everything goes through Bluetooth I figured it’d be fine. I’m the type that never really keeps any app running in the background.
As far as features, it has everything you could want but you can’t use any of them due to the stupid low battery life. On an average day, it tracks my steps fine and I occasionally ask it for a BPM. This will being the battery down to about 15% by the time I’m going to bed. Although, if you do anything else such as use more apps or track a workout with it for longer then 30 minutes, it will die on you before the sun sets. It’s definitely not meant for longer durations of tracking, which also means sleep tracking is non existent unless you manage to charge it right before bed and then use the watch. But not only will you need to charge it again once awake, I doubt it will get through the full night before it’s dead again.
Answering phone calls on this thing and trying to use the microphone is a joke. Unless you’re in a quiet, private area, you won’t be able to hear the caller. And to them, you either sound far away, or underwater.
Lastly is the Bluetooth interruptions. I feel like this is one of the biggest problems for most people because more and more devices require Bluetooth pairing, like car radios for example. For whatever reason, this watch will override whatever other device you try to use. The only fix I have for it is to completely turn off the Bluetooth on my phone, then turn it back on and connect to the device before the watch connects. Even the phone calls, when I answer a call using my truck, it’ll sometimes switch to my watch for no reason after a few minutes.
All in all, it’s not really worth the price. It’s got tons of features and looks pretty slick, but the terrible battery life, dumb random glitches, and the way it wants to prioritize itself above everything is just not worth it. If you catch this on sale for less than $200 maybe give it a go. But I would honestly save up the extra hundred or two for something better. Especially if you’re an IPhone user.

It has been a few days and I truly love this watch. It's by far the most beautiful watch in it's class. It's first and foremost a smartwatch designed to look amazing, with fitness tracker features pumped into it. The mobile app is well put together with a lot of customizable options, but I wish it had a couple of features. PROS
Beautiful watch.
Smooth and efficient touchscreen.
8G memory great for tons of apps.
Many customizable options.
GPS, NFC
Speaker is surprisingly loud.
The list goes on and on. CONS
Battery life is poor given all the hi-tech stuff that demand juice. First couple of days I literally watched the battery drain in a few hours, but after a few days of tweaking features it started about a day. Time only mode makes it last longer but you'll have to restart the watch to get out of that mode. Maybe a free extra car charger would help in the meantime.
Silicon band isn't the best quality, started showing streaks by day 2...but it's very comfortable though. WISH LIST
Battery last up to a week with GPS/NFC off.
Be able to store pics/audio/video through the app so they can be played or viewed later. The Fossil hybrid HR lets you load pic without FB. UPDATE
After almost 2 months I still love the watch...except the really bad battery life. It has never lasted beyond 36hrs (1.5days) even tho i turn off everything (NFC, GPS, wifi, tilt to wake, touch to wake, always on, speaker etc).
Basically, with btooth off at night, and notifications turned off 6hrs a day, it might last 24hrs. You have to not use it in order to be able to use it...yea, might defeat the purpose.
It would've been perfect if it could last a few days. Might just switch to the not so beautiful Samsung galaxy 3.

I will not buy another Fossil. After only 1.5 years of owning this Fossil Gen 5 I'm about to buy a Samsung watch because I'm fed up with recent performance of the Fossil Gen 5. Once bitten... Soon after the warranty expired I started having problems with battery life. The problems seemed to coincide with an update of the Fossil app, but I can't be certain of that. What I know is that certain battery mode options were removed. What's more, the update removed the OEM watch face I was using, and did not offer a new suitable similar watch face. In all fairness, a recent Fossil update restored the watch face that was removed. Despite running the same apps and same settings daily, battery life has always been unpredictable, but it used to last a day. Not so much any more even under very restricted usage. During the first year I was running with Gestures, WiFi, Bluetooth, heart-rate tracking, and NFC on, and without the always-on screen (instead a gesture would turn on the screen). Prior to the update the watch still had 30-50% of life remaining after a workday. Some days it would use battery at a faster rate than other days, and on the worst days it would automatically switch to extended mode in need of a charge. I would put it back on the charger before bed, then at bedtime use it overnight for sleep tracking. Overnight the battery drain was minimal. Now days, after the Fossil update (and after warranty expiration), the battery will run dry in four hours or less using the same settings I was using in the first year. It won't even last for a full night's sleep. Occasionally it will last a workday, but that is rare and I have not been able to figure out why some days are good. I have since turned off gestures, WiFi, and NFC. With those "desired" features disabled I can usually get a full day out of the watch, but at the expense of not using features that I want. And yes...I did do a factory reset hoping that would resolve the problems. No luck. The same issues were evident even before I started putting my few apps back on the watch. Still, and here's that unpredictable part again, occasionally when I take the watch off the charger, with the features still turned off, the watch starts churning through the battery at an alarming rate. In minutes it will turn itself off and the only way to turn it back on is to put it on the charger again. After the watch restarts it will indicate the battery is quite high...like 85%. So why did it shut down? In my opinion paying a premium price for just over one year of good use is not acceptable.  I'm hoping my next watch (from Samsung) will be a much better experience. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Original review: Nice looking watch, better battery life than expected. I'm pleased so far with this purchase. I was concerned about the battery life I would get, but so far battery life has not been an issue. Keep in mind that the first day or so the watch will be installing updates and new apps, and you will spend more time with it. But with all of that done, I'm getting well over a full day. It will still have ~25% of battery remaining when I put it back on the charger. This is even after using it all night for sleep monitoring! The only things I've turned off are the Always On display and the "OK Google" detection. For the display, I have activated gestures so that the display comes on when I rotate my wrist. As for OK Google, I just swipe left for the Google Assistant. I have not disabled heart rate tracking, and I let Google Fit monitor (heart/steps) all the time. Otherwise I'd forget to start it for a workout. As for charging, the watch charges to 100% in about an hour. I think the only con I can come up with is that this watch does not work with wireless charging (as do some Galaxy watches). It would be nice to be able to use the wireless back-to-back charging capability from my phone if I'm ever caught out without the phone's own charger. Hopefully Fossil will offer that next time around. As for being a watch, it works nice. It has apps for stopwatch and timers. I've not played much with the watch faces...I just picked one and probably will rarely change it. The watch works well with texting, email (including Outlook), calendar, and weather. I cannot yet speak using the watch for phone calls. I have not yet had an opportunity for a Dick Tracey wrist phone experience. I've recently installed the Sleep as Android app. So far it is impressive for what it is. I wear the watch overnight so I don't have to leave my phone on the bed. I have not yet tried the Cardiogram app. Other apps I've loaded: A great compass app (Steel 3d I think?). Google Pay...works great on the watch! Google Maps is loaded, but I have not used it yet. If you are into disc golf, you can keep score for multiple players on your watch using the UDisc app. I've done so several times and it has mostly worked great. Twice though it had a syncing issue where I had to finish keeping score on my phone. Both times I had opened the phone to access other features of UDisc, after which the watch scoring glitched. I think that's just a syncing bug that UDisc needs to figure out. As for size, I was concerned about that too. I do not like the oversized mongo watches. I prefer something less bulky. This is as large as I would want on my average sized wrists. Anything larger would be too big, I think. Anything smaller would not be usable for a smart watch. I bought the version with the brown leather band. The leather band is very nice...good quality. I also bought an after-market silicone band for playtime. I'd rather preserve the nice leather band for dressier occasions. I avoided buying a smart watch for years because I was not impressed by the battery life and the apps available. I am happy to say that I think they are worth it now. My only fear now is that Google will abandon Wear OS following the Fitbit acquisition. I hope not, because I think Wear OS is just now coming into it's own and can only get better as more developers and manufacturers adopt it.

Fossil is well knows brand of watches. I was looking for a Wearos based Smart watch for  last few months. I got opportunities to try other competing brands of smartwatches of the same price range. Fossil Gen 5 meet my expectations and I would recommend this watch because of the following pros:-
1. Size: the round watch fits perfectly on your wrists and give an executive look. You never feel the watch is heavy for your wrist.
2. Display: Scratch free and waterproof display works perfectly together with soft touch screen.
3. Buttons: Easy scrolling and fast responses middle button. The two up and down small buttons can be customised.
4. Interface: Initial configuration is very simple and easy.  WearOS allows you to connect with your smartphone quickly, easily. The connection seems to be very stable.
5. Install/Uninstall custom applications: Most of the necessary applications that you use in smartphone are available in WearOS. Google Play Store is pre-installed.
6. Activity tracking: Google for works perfect and synch with the phone.
7. Notification: Keep your phone away and see all the notifications in your writst. Reply to email/messages/WhatsApp/Mail/Facebook, etc..
6. Speaker & Microphone: in-built speaker and Microphone allow you to make/answer calls and get quick audible ouput from Google Assistant. Use Google Assistant as you use in your phone.
7. Memory: The watch has 1Gb RAM and approximately 5.6Gb internal memory got storage. The watch is relatively Faster compared to the other competing brands.
8. Battery modes: it has Daily/Extend/Custom/ Time-only modes. On average 1.5 days with all Daily mode. Time custom mode or Time only mode to save battery if needed.
9. Charger: Very light weight and not bulky charger. Comfortable to use.
10. Band - I used the Silicon band and I love it. It is water proof. Most commonly reportedly issues and tips. 1. Google Assistant audio response not working -- It works if you set the same language (eg. English U.S) in your phone and watch.
2. Unable to use watch mic and speaker to answer call -- For this you have to make sure that  I). 'Use phone audio in watch' is ON in watch, ii) While pairing with your blue tooth turn on the option for pairing audio in phone (go to blue tooth settings on your phone and click on the watch name, change settings).
3. Battery life: the watch holds many functions as a  mini wrist phone. To extend the battery life please use a suitable battey mode, turn off WiFi and locations if not necessary. Use 'low energy source' charger like USB port of your laptop. I hope you enjoy the watch.
Cons: I dont think is there something to highlight. Some people say the battery performance is poor, but it depends on their use and battey mode. ** It is an Unbiased review based on my experience and experience from my close friends. Thank you

I've had this for just under a week now and so far I really like it. My only legit complaint is the knobs and buttons on the side of the watch frame. I wish they were flat, I find that I accidentally long press the google assistant button a lot when I have to bend my wrist for more than a second. This hasn't been enough for me to return the watch though. I've just ended up pushing it up on my wrist a little higher and it seems to have helped. Additionally, the wrist straps are incredibly easy to swap. There's just a little silver nub where the band connects to the watch on the underside, you have to slide and hold it and the band comes out. Makes for incredibly easy changing between sport bands and nicer leather or metal bands for more formal situations. I took them both off and put them back on in less than a minute. Now for the big stuff -- I'll get right to it first and foremost since it is mentioned in a lot of reviews. The battery... **For anyone claiming to have terrible battery right out of the box, I suggest installing all the updates and doing a full overnight charge first. Battery performance was a little wonky during setup and while downloading and installing the updates, but after the first night it's been great. If you still have trouble then I suggest returning it or contacting Fossil for support for defective battery. *** BATTERY LIFE - I've customized some of the features, but for the most part they're all on. I've only turned off the sound and the ability to answer and take calls on the watch. I've never had to do take a call on my watch and I just see it as an irrelevant feature personally.  Additionally, I don't have the screen set to "always on" or "touch to wake" and instead use "tilt to wake". I start my day at 6:30a with 100% watch battery and arrive home about 5p every day and haven't fallen below 60% battery. This is with the features below on and with normal use by replying to texts, tracking walks with GPS, setting timers and alerts and occasionally using the google assistant. I have the following all turned on 100% of the time:
-GPS (only activates while tracking exercise)
-Wifi - always on and connected to my phone when not in bluetooth range
-Cloud backup
-Heart rate  monitoring (set to measure HR every 10 minutes all day)
-Google Fit Syncing Water resistance - According to the Fossil website, this watch is 3 ATM rated water resistance which means you can shower, wash your hands, get sweaty, etc without worrying. The 3 ATM rating means you should (in theory) be able to submerge your watch in water while swimming up to a depth of 100 feet. I personally don't know if I want to test this, but I have gotten it wet while washing my hands and its been fine. It's got a little bit of weight to it, so coming from a samsung gearfit that was rectangle and very light, it's taken some getting used to with the weight and round shape. It is a solid watch though. The screen is excellent, I've used it in a variety of lighting, including high-noon direct sunlight and the screen brightens up and it's perfectly readable. If you have bigger fingers, some of the buttons can be a little annoying to tap, but overall I've not had any major issue with the touch screen. The silicon strap is comfortable and has many notches for the perfect fit. As I said above, also incredibly easy to swap between the sport bands and a nicer leather or metal band. In conclusion, I was worried a little bit about getting a round watch and I had been keeping my eye out for a square option, but I haven't found any with Wear OS support (this was important to me for fitness tracking with google Fit). I'm glad I went with this option though because the watch looks great and I can get a nicer band to wear to more formal functions.

This is my second smartwatch. My first smart watch was a Huawei First Generation. I was very resistant at first getting a smart watch because I hate the square bezel look ( Apple). My Huawei still works but after about four years of ownership the LCD screen has been developing some "artifacts" ( LCD burn in, like the old plasma TVs).
I've been watching some smart watches for about 1 year now and had price alerts on them. The Fossil went considerably lower, to a price that I was comfortable with ( well under $200 ). I had to buy it. I had my eye on some Samsung Galaxy which I heard has amazing battery life but since my old watch was using Wear OS Google, I didn't feel like jumping ship to Tizen.
So, the good about the watch...it is a very good looking watch. I have the metal bracelet smoke. I like the fact that the screen on the outside is just as big as my Huawei (44mm I think) which isn't big. I have a medium size wrist. It is thinner and much lighter than Huawei 1st generation. The quality of the graphics is top notch. Set up was easy, painless on my Motorola Z4 phone. It stays connected, never drops off bluetooth. I didn't buy it to use the workout functions. They could be great, I don't know but if I wanted a workout watch I would buy an ugly square Garmin or whatever. I like to get texts, answer calls on it, do some speech to text replies. It works great for that. The screen brightness I think it is great. I keep it on auto or brightness at level 2.
So, now the bad. Biggest elephant in the room is the battery life. I kept it on the daily battery function with brightness on auto and most of the sensors off, but wifi and bluetooth on. I also keep the screen always on, but obviously it darkness a little after 3-5 seconds. I don't want that function off. I need to be able to see what time it is at a quick glance without needing to touch the screen, buttons, etc. I do get notifications but only messages ( WhatsApp, Viber and Messages). I don't really talk on it. I get about 15-25 WhatsApp messages per day, 20-25 texts and 3-4 Viber texts. I never check heart rate, never use GPS, NFC ( those are off). So my first day with it, the battery lasted 12 hours. My 4 year old Huawei lasts the same.??
I know the battery is only slightly bigger in Fossil than the Huawei but c'mon...I was expecting close to 24 hrs.
Also, the graphics of watch faces don't seem to cover the whole glass area. There's a tiny portion that isn't covered. Not a big deal but my Huawei is pretty much full screen. So I don't want to say Fossil is a bad watch. Not at all, but let me summarize. If I had paid $295 ( full price) for my Huawei 1st generation, I would  still be very pleased. If I would have paid $280 for the Fossil...hmm....??....not really. Battery let's it down. At the price I paid? I am not dancing with joy but I think is ok. I am torn between three and four stars but battery life is a big deal to me and because of this, I have a hard time giving it a four.
So, after a few days of playing with the setting I think I can get 16-18 hrs of battery which I guess it's ok. I turn Wifi Off, NFC off, heart monitoring off and I keep the brightness at 2 which for me is plenty. The watch is otherwise flawless. I decided to give it a four star.

I didn't really see a reason to own a wearable, but I was intrigued and I figured I'd see what all the fuss was about.  I wanted something that would sync up effortlessly with my Pixel 3, be highly readable, offer vibe, and have physical buttons.  I also wanted a round face (I find the square/rectangular ones ugly) and a metal band.  That narrowed the field down considerably.  The Galaxy Watch was a strong contender until I realized that many of the features are only active with Galaxy phones.  A buddy at work has a Garmin Fenix for twice the price of the Fossil.  I ordered the Fossil. Setup went easy and I had it running/synced in minutes.  The smoked stainless looks very classy, much better than the cheap, plasticky look of many of these devices.  There was plenty room in the bracelet even with my thick wrist - I ended up pulling two links (doable, but not very easy). I was initially disappointed with the size of the digital display font despite the large face, and none of the options on the WearOS app seemed to be "just right".  In addition, the battery life was not great for the first couple of days.  It took me some doing, but I found a free face on a third party app that looks and works terrific, plus it seems to have extended the battery life.  I can go 18+ hours on a full charge with the ambient display and BT on, however the charger works very quickly - popping on the charger for even a few minutes can add several hours. It's grown on me over the past few weeks and I am finding it very convenient to simply glance at it to see if the email/text is worth immediate attention.  Sending quick SMS/email replies is simple, either with the suggestions or (amazingly) the tiny keyboard.  Also, I get an SMS for dual layer authentication at work,12+ times a day, so that alone makes it very useful.  The speakerphone is OK only if you have HD voice.  I've toyed with some of the apps like Fit and Cardiogram.  They seem to do what they're supposed to do, but I was really in for the productivity. About the only complaint I have is the size of the crown/main button.  It's quite large and easy to press, so it's easy to accidentally depress any time I bend my wrist back, though wearing it a little higher on the wrist has helped. I'll edit if anything notable pops up, but for now I'll say that this was a very good choice at the price point.

I've been a wear OS (Android Wear) person pretty much since the first few watches came out.  I first got the Moto 360 and then the Huawei Watch and then the Huawei Watch 2.  In each instance, I've been fairly happy with the devices and the quality of the devices themselves.  Wear OS's problems are something else.  That's Google for you but given that I'm not a Samsung or Apple fan, I've done what I can to steer clear of those brands. My last Wear OS watch was the Huawei Watch 2 and I got a full 2 years of use out of that one.  Towards the end, it started to act up but that coincided with the release of the Gen 5 and the subsequent sale on Black Friday.  I was waiting for that to happen, hoping to eek out a few more days and weeks from my Huawei watch. So far, I've only had my Gen 5 for a couple of days.  It's hard to say how the battery life is after just those 2 days but I can say this.  The watch charges fast.  Real fast.  I was at 58% yesterday and I set it on the charger before I went to wash up for bed.  By the time I got back to the watch, it was fully charged.  That was maybe 30 minutes.  So I took the watch off the charger and I set it aside to see what the battery power would look like in the morning.  Not too shabby...it was at 91% this morning when I put it on. The Huawei watch had 768MB of ram (IF memory serves correctly) but even with that, Wear OS was still sort of slow and glitchy.  The 1GB on the Gen 5 definitely makes a difference.  It still has moments when it glitches and slows a little but it's a lot better.  I don't have nearly as many moments.  The watch is much more responsive and I think I will enjoy getting Google Pay back.  For the most part, I would have to say the Gen 5 is very smooth and responsive.  Coming from those other watches, I have nothing to complain about. Just a comparison...I also recently bought my wife a Samsung Galaxy watch.  Yes, I went to Samsung for her but she also owns a Samsung phone and doesn't have the same feelings about Samsung as I.  She started using it on Friday and even though she is happy with it overall, her battery isn't doing any better than my Gen 5.  She did get the smaller 42mm version with the smaller battery but I've seen numerous reviews about it saying that they get about 2&1/2 days to even 3 days out of a charge.  The wife might swing 1&1/2 days which is on par with what I'm seeing with the Gen 5.  But I can say one thing...helping her setup of the Tizen OS based watch made me want to stick with my familiar Wear OS watch even more.  You can't undo 4+ years of familiarity with a particular brand. About the Gen 5, I really like the big main button with the spinning dial.  The galaxy watch has the spinning bezel.  This has the spinning dial and I think I like that more than the spinning bezel.  Google assistant pulls up fast and it listens pretty well.  I was having some issues having it text my wife but that's something I'll check on further.  But at least between my phone and my watch, if I need to rattle off a quick message to someone while driving, I can voice activate things and speak my message and get it done that way without taking my attention off the road. So far, this watch has been everything that I wanted and hoped for.  I haven't tested the watch in water yet and I might not do that anytime too soon as I don't hit the water too often.  But I'm sure it's better than my Huawei watch and I took that into the pool a few times. From having my eye on this watch since it was announced to seeing it in store at a Fossil in Vegas and to finally getting it on my wrist, I can honestly say that this is the best Wear OS has to offer.  Fossil makes most of the watches with wear os.  The Emporio Armani Smartwatch 3 is a nice looking watch and it was just announced but I don't think it's worth the extra money.  The Gen 5 I think looks like a very nice watch.  It can work in any situation.  Much more versatile than my Huawei watch 2. Update:  I can definitely confirm that I love my gen 5. I've had it for a couple of weeks now. It feels so familiar to me but it runs so much smoother than all the previous watches. The battery life gets me a full day without any trouble. I'm using a watch face off the play store that gives me options to show on the screen. But even with this face and constant notifications all day, I'm somewhere between 45-60% after 16 hours. I could probably eek out 2 days in some situations but I'm an overnight charging person anyways so why bother trying for it... This is the best of wear os until the new chip gets released and maybe, something from Google gets released now that they own fitbit.

product_title: Fossil Q Men s Grant Stainless Steel Hybrid Smartwatch Color Grey Model FTW1139

reviews.review_body: Bought as a gift. Arrived in perfect condition. Recipient loves the features and design. Easily swaps out the link band to leather strap for an every day look.

I bought this watch with the intent to filter calls and texts while working. If it's not on the dial it's not worth looking at immediately. I hate the look of the blank smart watches! For me the only watch is a sleek analog design. But I wanted to try a hybrid type and see how i incorporated it into my routine without compromising design. So far it's helpful and not distracting. My smartphone is always on me, so advanced functions are still taken care of. I love having my watch alert me and give me basic information like who is calling/texting. This feels just like my other Fossils too. The battery is expected to last a year, but the replacement is about $1-2 and the tool to open the back comes with the watch. Fossil will replace it for free too! Pro:
Design
Usability
Don't have to ever charge
Quick recognition of iPhone information Con:
Replace the battery yearly (approximately)
Not very waterproof
Reports of the step tracker not working very accurately
Limited number of alert notifications
Other models (like my wife's Accomplice) don't share the same number of features
Great watch but unfortunately it cracked when wearing it in cold weather. Normally watch glass should be able to withstand this temperature range.

Purchased in Hawaii almost 2 1/2 weeks ago. Watch face has cracked already and I do not know why. The watch did not notify like it should have. It’s unfortunate that it costs as much as it did. Would have been better off with a gas station watch. Perhaps the company should change its name to suggest something more product quality appropriate.
its a great looking watch. The functions work. The smart watch capabilities are limited, but I was taught to read a watch and I like the classic watch face instead of a digital screen.

This is a light, comfortable, attractive and elegant watch. It has a black and silver linked band, and a smoky crystal over a roman numeral style dial.  The dial is a bit on the dark side and although its easily readable in bright light, it is hard to see in darker places. Setting up my Fossil Q was as easy as downloading the app and following the instructions - it took only a few seconds for my mobile device to find and pair with my watch. It was kind of fun watching the hands move around as it set the correct time (entirely on its own). There was a brief exercise using onscreen buttons to calibrate the watch, although truth be told I didn't need to make any adjustments.  The band is comfortable and easy to use - it has a push button release on the back.  I will probably end up removing a link or two though as the fit is looser than I like. There are three buttons on the side of the watch for enabling smartwatch features. The features are limited, but useful. You can control music playback, receive vibrating messages, notifications, select contacts for expedited calling. It also has some health tracking features, like a step counter and a sleep monitor.  I suspect that, like many other software driven items, the feature set will grow with time.

I was able to connect this very nice looking 'low-key smartwatch' to my cell phone without any difficulty at all. Low-key meaning that it is mostly meant to be a nice-looking, fashionable watch but it is still able to pair with your phone to offer some smartwatch-like capabilities. The most obvious difference from most traditional smartwatches is that there is no digital screen nor any lighting. Unlike some of the other Fossil smartwatches, this model has no USB charger and you need to change the battery like a traditional watch. It does include a "Q" shaped key to let you access the battery, but it can also be opened with a coin. It was kind of cool to see the dials move very fast during the pairing - this process is basically to let you know that the phone has successfully paired to your phone via bluetooth. Just keep in mind that you will need to download an app on your smartphone in order to take advantage of this function. It is able to count the number of steps that you take, but this is probably not intricate enough for sporting activity - just for general daily walking. It also has a sleep quality monitor, but I personally don't think that this watch is comfortable for sleeping. I would also mention that this watch is on the heavy side - which I personally like but some people might not.
Beautiful watch. Only issue is that the battery gives out quickly.

If you want the look of a classic watch with the ability to receive notifications that's pretty much what you're getting. I picked this up for my husband and he liked it for about a week before he found that he preferred a regular watch or a smart watch, the hybrid just wasn't for him.

I'm having tons of fun getting acquainted with Fossil's Q Grant hybrid smart watch. Fossil is a worldwide brand who has leveraged its ingenuity in watchmaking to launch Fossil Q, an innovative line of hybrid smart watches. I believe the Q Grant is the perfect watch for today's lifestyle. I like that Fossil respects the artistry and tradition of fine watchmaking. The stainless steel construction and intricate design makes a very favorable impression, indeed.  The twist is that unlike my grandfather's watch, I can connect the Q Grant to the Fossil Q app on my smartphone; opening up some very interesting and useful possibilities. To begin, I downloaded the Fossil Q app to both my tablet and iPhone. Pairing the watch took only a few moments.  When complete, the time hands on the watch automatically moved to the time indicated on my tablet (I presume this auto sync will eliminate the daylight savings time hassle going forward, too).  I found the very clean, uncluttered interface of the Q app to be intuitive and easy to use. The Fossil Q app allows me to use the Q Grant to track my sleep, steps and fitness goals. The app can also be used to set alarms. A press of the button on the lower right can be used to stop/play music, ring the phone and take photos.  I think it's simply an elegant solution to making online technologies accessible when using a device of high integrity. I've attached a selfie to this review that I took with the Q Grant. All I did was set my iPhone on a table with the camera app open. Then I pressed the button on the Q Grant. Snap - my iPhone captured the moment!  What a great way to take photos virtually hands-free. Fusing the best of old and new technologies, I highly recommend Fossil's innovative Q Grant smart watch to everyone.
Beautiful watch.  I had to return it though because it was very heavy and bulky.

I will preface this by saying we are pretty low tech in our household, but open to tech that improves our lives.
I use my fitbits pretty much daily.
We wear watches.
My husband hates the look of fitbits, so i thought this smart watch would achieve same purpose First, he didn't like the size or weight. Second, he said it is difficult to read the face, needs lighting and crystal clear face. Third, he doesnt want a watch telling him about missed calls. If he isnt carrying phone its because he is choosing to wisely disconnect for a while. So, after trying this, he agreed to use fitbit as lesser of two evils to monitor fitness. Functions worked well, although step counter signficiantly different from fitbit, phone, and old school pedometer when we tested.

Beautiful watch but very hard to read in dark or dim lit situations. “Hybrid smart watch” functions are a joke- pony up the cash for an Iwatch if you want a smart watch- not only is this hybrid impractical, it is also useless unless your iPhones Bluetooth is always on, eating your phone battery up. If it was back lit I’d give it two more stars but a watch that needs a new battery 3-6 months, is not waterproof, does not take pictures, does not “play” music, or accurately monitor steps, calories, and sleep(which the devices advertises, but disclosed in manual that accuracy is not promised or guaranteed) is not worth the asking price. I might pay half of what they’re asking if it wasn’t given to me as a gift based on the watches over-all stunning beauty. Beautiful watch, but beauty is pretty darn expensive for being a heavy, non-practical time piece

My husband loves this watch, and no wonder - it's good-sized and heavy - and a Fossil, a brand we both love. On top of that, it's a fitness tracker. Until now, he has used an app on his phone for tracking his steps - he doesn't want to wear a typical fitness tracker, but loves knowing he's walked his five miles every day.  Thus, this big manly-looking watch is absolutely perfect for him. This smart watch pairs with your phone and is able to notify you about texts and emails from the contacts you choose. It will also track your sleep habits if you want it to and  lets you set up goals and check them off if you're so inclined.  It's easy to connect the watch to your phone - you just download the app and get going. This chrome and black watch, with its dual-tone stainless steel wristband, is heavy and solid on your wrist, which is exactly what my guy likes.  The face has Roman numerals. It's good-sized but the lack of contrast makes it hard to see for older eyes, especially at night. That's the only reason I knocked off a star. The watch operates on a battery, not a USB charger, but the great thing is that you can change the battery yourself - it even comes with a little tool to open the battery compartment. All in all, it's a beautiful watch if you are into traditional analog timepieces with the added smart features.

This is a beautiful watch but it does have a few issues. it is a bit heavier than average, which is fine for a regular stylish watch, but if you are wearing it for its fitness tracking capability, then you might be wary since you may be tempted to take it off when you get home from work and get comfortable. It was a bit too big for me at first but I easily took out a couple of links and now it fits really well. It was packaged beautifully and came with everything I needed. I do enjoy the smart feature of being alerted with the hand movements whenever my friends or family are texting or calling me. It's a really cool feature that I haven't seen on any other watch. My main complaint with this watch is that it is not backlit, making it very difficult to read. I would not buy this again unless a light were added.

I've enjoyed using a fitness tracker, but it didn't function as well as a watch. If you are considering this watch, it's likely you want it for the watch feature and look first, and as a fitness tracker second, but there's a feature in the watch that's hardly mentioned but that owners of this style of watch are likely to find very useful. It's called Goal Tracking. Yes, the watch can track the traditional steps and sleep, but it can also tracks Goals. It's one of the three sections (see screenshot). At first it seemed like it was just fitness goals, but no. You customize the goal. One example they give is "Say hello to someone new today." You perform your goal, and then you press the lower button on the watch and it catalogs that you achieved you goal. Now for professionals and executives, this can be a very powerful tool. Say you want to accomplish a certain task each day. This could be related to work (spend 30 minutes sharpening the saw, for example), or spend 10 mindfulness minutes, Spend 30 minutes writing, or make a sales call, etc. Point is, you can customize the goal, and then each time you reach the goal, you can track it by pressing the button. I thought it would be silly, but it's one of my favorite features. Now on to the other features -- Adjusting the links -- The watch does not come with a link adjuster, just FYI. So to remove a link to adjust the band size, you'll need a link adjuster tool. The watch does come with a tool (in the shape of a Q) that can be used to remove the battery casing. -- Face Size -- This is a large watch, and it took some getting used to, but I like it. -- Coloring -- The grey background as well as the grey hands blend together a little when making a quick glance to the watch. I've gotten used to it, and overall the look is elegant. It'd be interesting to see if other owners feel the same. The minute hand is colored orange at the tip as well as the step indicator. so that helps. -- No Light -- My biggest regret is that the watch doesn't have a light. Really wish it had that. The hands do glow in the dark, but it's pretty subtle. -- As a Fitness Tracker -- The steps are accurate as far as I can tell. It's different from my other fitness tracker, but after counting steps for a bit, the Fossil Q seems pretty accurate. The step data can import into the Apple Health App but as of this writing, the Sleep Data cannot. Maybe they'll get that fixed. Accuracy here was similar to my fitness tracker when tested against each other. I love that at a quick glance, I can see the progress of my fitness goal from 0% achieved to 100%. I don't have to press any buttons to see progress. It helps me be more conscious of my fitness goal because I immediately see my progress with each look at the watch. -- Other Features -- The watch can be used as an alarm, with a press of one of the buttons, you can view the date, or even another time from a time zone you select which is handy if you need to do business with a company in another time zone or on the other side of the world. The watch vibration notifications can be adjusted in strength. The lowest setting is almost imperceptible. You can set vibration notifications for texts and calls, but for me, that's not as handy. I don't need something to connect me to calls and texts. The fitness and goal tracking are the most beneficial features for my use, but the other features are there if you want them. -- The App -- I was surprised by the elegant design of the app. Good job on that, Fossil. I haven't noticed errors or crashing in use with an iPhone. -- Do I miss my separate Fitness Tracker Watch? -- No. I've found myself using this watch exclusively throughout the day. It's a great blend of tradition, style, and function. -- Two Word -- Love it.

This is a really nice looking watch with a big face, which I like. It has the watch feel that one wants. Although this watch weighs 6 ounces, which in my book is on the heavy side. Out of the box it easily sync'd with my phone so from there all I had to do was use the features on my phone to talk to my watch. We were curious how this would be a smart watch and show its use. If the face showing analog and will switch to a digital face? If so cool! The answer is no. The watch itself tells you the time and the day. It will notify you of alarms you have set on your phone. It will control the volume on your phone and you can set it up to work with your phones camera to take pictures. Which is pretty cool. But most communication is done with your device. Removing links to adjust size was easily done as well as the smaller adjustments in the band coupling. So after making size adjustments and syncing it to my phone I started to play with it. I'm really curious about the step counter. My phone has one inside so that went in the back pocket and the watch on the wrist. The numbers didn't match, not even slightly. One has to be moving their arms in order to get the step counter to register steps. The problem with that is if you are working on something that requires a lot of hand movements it over counts your steps. But on the other hand if you spend your time hauling stuff to and fro with your hands then your steps will not be counted. I'm sure it all comes out in the wash with an active day. My last observation is the crystal, it is tinted a smokey tint. Which makes it harder to see in darker rooms and at night. The hands are glow in the dark which helps if you a bit. There is no backlight to illuminate the face for viewing. I like the watch but it is much heavier than I would like and was hoping the "smartwatch" capabilities would be better. It is a nice dress watch though and has that classic analog look we like. I do wonder about the battery and how often I will need to change it.

This is my first foray into smart watches, and I have some issues.  Let’s start with the basic concept.  As smart watches go, this one is pretty minimal.  I am an analog guy, and this is an analog watch, which is the only reason I would consider it.  So, its smart watch functions are minimal.  Mostly, it is a health tracker.  The main issue with it as a health tracker is its weight.  In order for a watch to work as a health tracker, you have to wear it consistently, and a watch of this weight just doesn’t work in that capacity.  Fit bits work because they are so light that people will just wear them all the time.  I won’t because I want a real watch.  I prefer lighter watches these days, though, and with something of this weight, which is heavier than the truly slim, minimalist watches I like these days, I certainly won’t wear it constantly.  I will take it off when I get home from work, and won’t put it on until I leave in the morning, and that defeats a lot of the purpose.  If a heavier watch is not something you will wear 24/7, then this won’t work as a fitness tracker for you. Other than the fitness tracker, its “smart” capacities are minimal.  It will notify you of texts and emails from selected contacts, and the hands on the dial will rotate in a coded way to show you who is trying to contact you.  That’s about it.  That isn't the most efficient way to convey information, and that doesn't really impress me.  Other than that, it’s a big, heavy-ish watch.  It's not one of those gargantuan monstrosities, but a while ago, Vine gave me one of those nice, slim little Lucien Piccard things that I often wear, and in terms of weight, there just isn't any comparison. Also, keep in mind the metal band problem.  Metal bands have an intrinsic “rounding error” problem with regard to the size of your wrist.  You have to remove a fixed number of whatdoyoucallems, and the band will likely be either too tight or too loose.  If it is too loose, you may not get the best readings.  I didn’t think much of the readings I saw, particularly the step tracker. Do I have anything positive to say?  It’s a nice-looking watch.  Good feel, and actually, the band release is kind of cool.  On its own, this is a decent watch.  Worth wearing, and my wife says that it works as a decent, not-too-dressy kind of thing.  I'll have to trust her judgment on that.  I just don’t think much of the smart features, given the weight, and my unwillingness to wear it at all times.  However, the price is based on the smart features, making this, in my opinion, overpriced.  But, that depends for you on how heavy a watch you like.  I like slim, light watches.  If that isn't you, then go for it. If you are willing to wear a heavier watch at all times, and want an analog watch that does step-tracking, etc., then this is probably a good choice for you.  However, this is not the droid I was looking for.
Absolutely love this watch.
My dad loves his new watch
My husband absolutely loves this watch. No complaints.
Exactly what I wanted, connected and waterproof
Perfect Fathers Day gift! My husband loves it!
My husband loves it and wears it every day

very nice watch
a gift, and he loved it
It took a minute to set up but after that works as they say
Great seller. Nothing but good things
Really enjoy the watch worth the money
Love It ! works great ! Looks sharp ! great gift for a guy ...
I love this smartwatch! quick shipping, excellent conditions ans more beautiful than image!
Got this for my birthday.  This is a solid, great looking watch.
My boyfriend loved this watch, I didn’t realize it was a smart watch which was an added bonus!
It stop working after six months. too late to return it.
really cool watch.. not need to recharge... it has battery and bluetooth function .. so cool
Love this watch I have 12 fossil watches at this time and by far this is my fave...
I have replaced the glass two times in 11 months only had it 12 months

No issues connecting to phone or updating time. A nice just-smart-enough watch. Activity tracking seemed to only track half of my steps (just my left foot?) and the entire face cracked after 4 months.
Looks awesome
Classoc look. Awesome concept. Works well most time, sometimes does not link to app properly.

I love this watch.  I wanted a smart watch but also wanted a classic watch,  this is the best for needs.  So many options and i don't get alerts from every contact or phone call only the important ones.  I wish i would have bought it earlier.
Works great, exactly as described. I could think of some better uses for some of the function buttons, but pretty good overall. Plus it looks great!
Honestly I was expecting more for the price. It a beautiful watch but it’s not durable. My husband’s going watch broke after only a few months use.

While I love the smartwatch features, the grey face is darker than the pictures make it out to be and the black numbers and grey hands are hard to read in anything but bright light (because it doesn't have a backlight). I'm returning it and getting a different color (model FTW1158--white numbers and hands with a black face).

Not sure I am happy to know how inactive I really am, but it is good to know how well i sleep and it is going to motivate me to start doing more walking once the weather gets nicer.  Oh and it isa good looking watch that keeps great time too

Horrible Fitness Tracking.  It looks awesome and most of the features are amazing BUT if you are looking for this to be an accurate Activity Tracker then DO NOT WASTE your money.  I wore this side by side with My Fitbit charge and tested against a 3rd Device(IPhone 6s).  Both the Fitbit and IPhone were very close to one another.  The Fossil Q Grant Gen 2 was horrrriiiiiiibleeee.  Its not even close.  I would walk 3 miles and the Fossil q would be off more than a mile(2000 +steps).  I worked with Fossil to exchange the watch because no way the watch could be that far off.  Once I received the replacement I still saw the huge discrepancy in step calculation.  Text notifications and linking the watch to the phone to control your music on the IPhone work great.  I cant say how disappointed I was with the Fitness Tracker portion though, VERY POOR JOB.

My husband loves this watch! It's very sexy and fits his style perfectly. He wears it to the gym to track his steps, but it also looks great when he dresses up for work. It is such an attractive watch and you can't even tell it's a smart watch.

Purchased this watch in February. Immediately noticed that the step count was inaccurate. Wore the watch and my wife's Fitbit blaze for a walk (on the same arm) and the difference in steps was incredible. This watch only logged about 2500 steps to the blaze's more accurate 6500 steps. (Distance confirmed via GPS and driving the route.) Additionally, shortly after the "support window" had closed, the glass bezel broke. A huge crack right through the center of the dial. I have had a lot of watches from many different brands and I have NEVER cracked the bezel before, even with much rougher wear and over longer periods of time. Now I'm stuck with a broken watch that doesn't log my activity properly. Pros: Bluetooth notifications work, especially handy when I walk away from my phone, I know when I've missed a call or text.
  Stylish, minus the cracked bezel Cons: step count is inaccurate
  Bezel inexplicably cracked after 2.5 months of occasional, daytime wear
  Return/warranty period too short Overall, I'm disappointed with this purchase and would NOT recommend this watch.

I decided to buy this watch because, like everyone else, I had a smart watch and I was sick and tired of charging it every single day. So I came across the concept of a "hybrid watch" here. Pros:
*Looks and feels like a real fossil watch, not a silly gadget
*The pedometer seems to be pretty accurate (until your battery gets low - see cons)
*The app is very detailed about the types of steps and sleeps you get
*You can set multiple app notifications to a single digit alert (I have Messenger, Text, and WhatsApp all on 1 for example)
*YOU DO NOT NEED TO CHARGE THE THING AT ALL!!! (I literally only take my watch off to shower) Cons:
*No illuminating watch hands - this is the biggest gripe honestly. The watch has a naturally dark background, so if you are in a poor lit or even dark room, you will not be seeing anything on this watch.
*The App regularly crashes the first time I load it (Samsung Note 9), but works fine after loading it again.
*There is no clear indication when to replace the battery. I went 7 months before replacing mine, however about 5 months in my pedometer went nuts and started registering an insane amount of steps. No other issues with the watch whatsoever. I finally decided to replace the battery issue and the pedometer is back to normal again. So I guess the crazy pedometer registers is your best indication to swap out that battery. Summary:
Overall, I love the watch simply because I do not care for charging of smart watches at all when all I like are the notifications and pedometer, which these hybrid watches have without the need to regularly charge them. I would definitely recommend a hybrid watch to anyone that does not need all the extra bells and whistles on their wrist, but still would like those added amenities mentioned above.

The quality is better than expected. The metal nor the quartz glass gets scratched easily. I wear this daily and even when i sleep. Not one scratch on the watch face at all. I only have one ding due to hitting something metal with my hand. But even then it's tiny and hardly noticable. It's a perfect blend of a classic watch with smart watch capabilities. This is exactly what i have been wanting. The battery is easily replaced and lasts quite a while actually. The bands were easy to fit to my wrist (you need a watch repair kit for this). The watch face is easy to read and can be calibrated for precision. Overall a great watch, i was skeptical having had a couple smart watches before. But this is the perfect blend i was looking for and needed. Minimalist smart watch with a beautiful watch face.

Got this for my husband for Christmas.  Paid $175.00!!!  I ordered on 11/27/17 to make sure I got it in time for Christmas.  It quit working last week (2/12/18).  Went online to see about a return and was told the return dates had closed effective 1/31/18.  What kind of return policy is only 60 days?!  I am extremely annoyed!!!!  For $175.00 it should have worked more than 6 weeks!!!

Love the quality. Clean sleek and nice weight with adjustable linkage band.  More features than expected.  Has smart watch capabilities  WITHOUT  the cheesey plastic band that most have... Those  seem gross and rather grade-schoolesk in my opinion and that coupled with  square primitive digital readout looked like smart watches for dummies and why I haven't been inclined to consider a smart watch until this .  Others commonly look generic and are simply  a dime a dozen.  This watch stands far outside of any smartwatch I've encountered. I collect regular Fossil watches this one will be the star that never sees the inside of the watch box on my dresser. Self charging! That's amazing.. Like we need another device to charge. Fossil hybrid offering the style and luxury and the look and feel that others lacked all the while integrating the technology capabilities that are almost required of our accessories in this ever advancing "smart"  device  modern world.
This watch and its unique style and intricate gears shown in the face are eye catching.  It looks more expensive than it was. This is a great gift for a gadget loving guy who has everything. Just got it so learning the features will update later. Very pleased so far.

product_title: Samsung Galaxy Watch 42mm GPS Bluetooth Midnight Black US Version
product_description: Live a stronger smarter life with Galaxy Watch at your wrist rest well and stay active with built in health tracking and a Bluetooth connection that keeps everything at your wrist Plus go for days without charging Go nonstop for days on a single charge The wireless charger lets you power up without slowing down Average expected performance based on typical use Results may vary Battery type and size 270mAh Available in 2 sizes and 3 colors the Galaxy Watch offers stylish watch faces so realistic they hardly look digital Plus choose from a collection of interchangeable bands Pairs with both Android and iOS smartphones via Bluetooth connection Compatible Devices Samsung Smartphone Non Samsung Android Smartphone Android OS 5 0 and above RAM 1 5GB and above iOS 9 0 and above iPhone 5 and above Included in box Galaxy Watch Additional Strap Large and Small included Wireless charging Dock Travel Adaptor Quick Start Guide User Manual Warranty 1 Year Standard Parts and Labor OS Tizen 4 0 Note Kindly refer user manual before use

reviews.review_body: I just bought this watch to see if I would like it enough to get a data plan and use it when my phone was not in range. Thought it would be convenient to have it notify me of a caller when I'm walking the dog and may not want to stop to get the phone out of my pocket. Very glad I didn't go all out. It syncs to my phone just fine, but the advertised battery life must be when it is in power saving mode and who wants that all the time. I maybe get half a day and the power is so low that it gives me a notice to put in power saving mode. I followed the directions by charging completely before using for the first time, too. It's a nice watch but I could have just kept using my Fitbit.

I've been using the watch for some time now and it's been great so far! The messaging, notifications, voice system, and multiple functions have all met my expectations. The battery life is great as well with light usage such as notifications and reminders.  It definitely rivals the Apple watch and other competitors.  So for I haven't had any issues with it and it's been worked flawlessly.  I'd definitely consider purchasing it if you're into the smartwatch market!

Great little watch for the price cant wait for a new model to come out. It always said I was sleeping after laying down to long, I love how you can change features and update from your phone as well and great features so far.

Just so you know...the seller advertises this as a "US Warranty version" that is not the case...I went to the Samsung web site to register my watch and it wouldn't recognize the serial #...so I got on the phone w/ Samsung customer service...they found the serial # in their system...BUT it was manufactured in South America, therefore NO warranty...the writing on the outside of the box is in Spanish...just BEWARE...also there were 2 other UPC stickers w/ serial #'s over the original...if you don't care about a warranty...carry-on...if you do...buy elsewhere...it's still a very good watch...works mostly great...which is why I gave 5 stars...

Having used a pebble time steel for most of 2016 up till the time of me writing this review it's a nice upgrade. Battery is no where near as good as the time steel but that's to be expected considering the plethora of features this watch has.
My only real complaint here is the fact that if you wear it daily, expect the bezel to scratch and scuff fairly easily which has unfortunately already happened to mine.
In order to remedy this I went and bought a protective silicone/rubber protective case from Spigen and hopefully it'll do the job.

Wow that is all i can say, it works wonders, when I have it set to a classic watch face people think its a real geared watch, they cannot tell the difference, then i switch it to something like my cat's picture and it blows them away. Its great

This is a replacement/upgrade from GearFit 2.  No blemishes were found during unboxing.  Excellent display quality.  The size and weight is comparable to a dive watch, even a bit smaller than a Casio Tough Solar on the wrist.  Sleep tracking has more detail, 4 stages vs 3.  There are TONS of watch faces available the Galaxy store.  The price made me happy.  Battery life in the first week is acceptable, even better in airplane mode.  I'm finding it better to use the auto workout tracking for better battery life but that sacrifices heart rate data.  I'll update with pics  and more performance info.

Love my Galaxy!  Worked great out of the box and very easy to set up.  Love the spinning face dial to select apps.  Goes 2 to 3 days on a charge, but also charges quickly (within a couple of hours when fully drained).  Love the variety of available watch faces for free, and tons more if you want to buy them.  Wasn't sure how the phone app would work, but it works surprisingly well.  It's a great hands-free feature when driving or working with both hands.  Sound quality is good, too.  Also like the larger face diameter, which is nice for us older guys.  Great, great watch!!

Overall, I really like this watch. It looks and operates good. The apps available cover the entire spectrum of functions. From sleep to exercise to clock functions, it's very user friendly. when I first got it, I had a Motorola phone and that pairing didn't work well. The phone was several years later and didn't support some of the newer features. I was ready for a new phone anyway so got a Samsung phone; the combination is great. I would suggest that anyone in the market for a smart watch should put this one in their consideration list.

I like the functions, but I wish it were a little lower profile. I have a Galaxy phone, so it made sense to also get a Galaxy watch, but I prefer the lines of the Apple watch. I wish there was a more streamlined option in the Galaxy family (yes, I know there's the active watch, but it's got a larger face, which is also a turn off for me). Otherwise I'm happy with it.

I was looking for a less expensive watch after my last one was destroyed in a motorcycle accident. I know this is not the newest model but i love it. the features give me what i need. I am sure the newer ones are sooo much better but i don't need the latest and greatest. This one does everything i need and all i want.

I've had the watch for some months now. To be fair to Samsung I bought this watch mostly as a sports watch, not a smart-watch, but I'm disappointed either way. It's simply a massively underwhelming sports watch. Once or twice it didn't even keep the activity I did and saved. The heart-rate monitor is terrible, but most wrist-measuring watches are, so I can't complain too much about that. The watch itself, despite being tight on my wrist, wobbles about when I am mountain biking and actually hurts me. Samsung's own Health app is useless.  I had a Garmin before which has a whole massively detailed online portal where you can see everything you've done and overlay it with Google Maps etc. Samsung has no online portal at all and looking at it on your phone is basic at best. Despite all the reviews it's not all that easy to use as a smart watch.  It's too small for starters.  Samsung's original smart watch was much better looking IMO and square, which makes sense.  Round may look better in some devices, but is totally stupid and impractical for a smart watch. The dial on the front works well most of the time to move between screens, but if that's the way to measure a smart watch then it's just sad. I've yet to see a smart watch with any real use.  Better to get a sports watch which has some rudimentary smart features than a smart watch with some rudimentary sports features.  Complete waste of money

This watch has to be the best watch on the android side of things.  The battery last almost 2 days for me, and does a great job tracking my fitness. I'm a runner, so this feature is a must! I really like the round, turntable bezel, which makes for great user interface. It does include a heartrate monitor, and a sleep monitoring feature that's very useful. I'm using a Samsung phone, so the synchronization seems very seamless. It comes with a rubber watch band right out of the box, this is great for active folks. The watch rubber band is stylish, so I didn't have a need to replace it for another one. Great buy for any android user looking for a smartwatch that works well with android.

This is not Android Wear. It's Samsung's Tizen.
As my 4th smart watch, and as a Technology Pro, I hoped I would be able to adapt Tizen to my needs. This was not the case, and I ended up returning it - a process Amazon made very painless.
CONS:
-No Google Maps integration that I could get working, whatsoever, even after attempting several Samsung apps.
-No 'OK Google' at all - instead I have the dreaded Bixby. Not even close. You're fired, Bixby.
-Samsung Account needed for nearly any app, or major feature - including watch faces.
-Samsung's store has very limited selections compared to Android Wear.
-Lack of flexibility: Requires Samsung apps be used as default apps on  your phone to sync to the watch, like Messaging, Samsung Mail app for calendars, and more. Nope, Nope, Nope!
-NFC Payments requires use of Samsung Pay, and a Samsung account to track my history. NOPE!
-No Google Fit - Requires 'Samsung Health', and a Samsung account.
-Price is stratospheric for a device locked into crap software. PROS:
- Hardware was light, dial was smooth, screen was nice. Essentially, this watch is a marketing angle to get you into bed with Samsung account related software. Period. The Samsung Suite of software lacks flexibility, even at the watch-face level the selections were disappointing. The amount of free software is incredibly limited, and the pay software for the Tizen OS is minimal and under-developed compared to Android Wear. I returned it and decided to wear an older Android Wear device instead.

Do not buy this watch from the seller called "Globus Projects Ltd" if you are looking for a US version, since their products are not as described and they appear to be sending out international versions with stickers on the box claiming to be the US version. Watch arrived with packaging in a foreign language. Unable to use Samsung Pay on this watch, which is not a deal breaker for me. Otherwise the watch works great so far. Battery life is excellent. Very easy to connect to phone and set up, even though the default language was also set to a foreign language. Easy to read notifications and respond to messages with brief replies. Works well for controlling music playing on phone. Would definitely recommend this smartwatch, especially to use with a Samsung phone.

I purchased this device eight months ago and was happy for the first couple months. About two months in, I had to send the watch in for service when the accelerometer seemingly went out as sleep data was no longer being recorded (The factory resets and software updates were in vain). From a consumer standpoint, I don't think the quality is really there with the money you have to spend on a watch like this. I just can't say the hardware was properly designed with the problems I've been experiencing. Now, just a few months later, I'm having to send the device in again since the battery won't last longer than 8 hours on "low-power mode." Why should I be acting as a Beta tester when this watch is already in production!? After sleuthing the message boards, I found multiple complaints from other customers with the same device. All Samsung had been responding with was "turn off the features [you paid for] to increase the battery life." Very helpful, Samsung. You guys really know how to make a customer feel valued. When I purchased this watch I was expecting a complete product and better performance for the money I spent. Strangely enough, Samsung's return policy is not longer than about a month. Funny how things have a tendency to fall apart after the warranty expires. Now I realize I shouldn't expect much out of Samsung's wearables ¯\_(?)_/¯. If I ever do go with another smart watch, I'll be steering clear of anything Samsung. Buyer beware.

I love this watch. I've had it for a few days now. Replaced my fitbits because I'm tired of them dying in under a year all the time. Battery life sucks compared to Fitbit, but I get why. I will have to charge every other day instead of twice a week now. Annoying but not a big deal really. And their app gets 1 star because it sucks. It helps you do some settings, but you can't see fitness tracking info like you can on Fitbit. That is where Fitbit wins, their app is exponentially better.

You cannot go wrong with this watch if you have a Samsung phone (im sure it's compatible with other phones but to use features best it works amazing with my Note 9). This is the bluetooth version. I can reply to texts, answer calls and even use it to talk. This is the 42mm and not going to lie, i have big hands and this watch still looks good on my wrist. I get many compliments on how nice the watch looks. I wear it to business meetings and many people glance at it and have had someone tell me it looks real elegant. My first watch was a TicWatch E which was a great first smartwatch but had to upgrade to this one. It is not laggy and very responsive. Would highly recommend.

I main bought so I could use the GolfPad App on a watch, and it works amazing I absolutly love using it out on the course.  It is also very comfortable, battery last about as long as you would expect a smart watch to run (about 2 days unless your tickering with it alot then about a day), i just put it on the charger every day after work and its never dead.  Only complain i have it that if you have tattoos on your wrist the heart rate monitor isnt going to work threw your tattoos.

I have been wearing this watch almost everyday since i bought it. Not a single scratch on the screen. There are a few dents on the metal itself, but that is bound to happen. It would look better with the metal clasp for more formal occasions. It is waterproof which i tested by swimming in a pool and a lake. If you are swimming in chlorine, definitely make sure to wash that shit out or it will crust up on the band and clog up the speakers. Overall, great smart watch for the price!

I very much like this watch. It has all the functions I wanted and some. I came from a Fitbit Versa 2 and compared to that this Samsung blows that watch out of the water.  It is much easier to change watch faces on the Samsung. It is appealing to the eye and flows well with my style. I would recommend this watch to anyone with an Android-based phone. I understand this watch even works with an iPhone though I cannot verify that since I do not own one. Once again I am very pleased with this purchase and will recommend to friends.

This was my first smartwatch so maybe there are better alternatives out there, but for me this watch greatly exceeded my expectations. I really got it to help with time tracking and notifications becasue I never have my phone on my person. But the activity tracking, sleep tracker, and even having the weather right there are great. Also the heart rate monitor and tracking hikes or long walks is excellent. There are so many great looking free watch faces that there isn't really a need to purchase.
Battery is two days with moderate to heavy usage. Three easily if you turn off the constant heart rate monitor. Easily syncs with any app you choose. It defaults to Samsung apps but all you need to do is turn on notification for Google calendar and it will automatically show notifications on your watch.

I love almost everything about this smartwatch, it's amazing. Especially the battery life, I get 3 days of constant use easily.  My only complaint is the bezel, it seems from the first few days I've owned it till now just a few weeks in, that it has a grinding noise like something is stuck under the bezel and makes it hard to rotate at times.  I wonder if a small hair or something has made it's way in there.  It's very very frustrating that this can happen at all let alone so soon from me owning it. Running it under water helps to solve this but it's only temporary as it seems to come back over time.

First of all, I am in the Android/Samsung camp when it comes to phones.  This watch is a really nice complement to this experience.  The round face and rotating bezel are the looks I like in a watch.  Personally I don't like square watches.  The rotating bezel works flawlessly and makes navigating the watch fairly intuitive. The watch is comfortable to wear all day and night.  I only take it off to charge every two days.  Yes the battery lasts more than two days. The best features are notifications work great and easily customized.  I use it for fitness tracking.  Starting and stopping workouts are intuitive.  I noticed the heart rate sensing is just as accurate as my chest strap. Overall I am pleasantly surprised how much I like this watch.

My husband and I got matching watches and WE LOVE THEM! I mainly use mine to listen to music at work and converse on the phone discretely. I use the step counter as well as the heart rate monitor to keep track of my stress. They even have a breathing app to help if your stress levels are high. This watch has so many features that we both appreciate like the step counter as well as the ability to reply to and read text messages as well as talk on my phone right from the watch! The charging stand is also a great addition. There is almost nothing my phone can do that this watch can not.. we absolutely love it!

This is a good smart watch for first time users transitioning from traditional wristwatches. It has the look of a fashion watch. The rotating bezel is great and one of a kind and allows you to navigate the watch with touching the screen. One downside I encountered was that after a year of use, the sensor became loose and didn't stay in place. This caused the watch to think I wasn't wearing it, so it kept locking me out and was no longer usable.

This is my 3rd smartwatch and seems to be just what I was looking for. Tracks my heart beat really well, way better than my previous two models. Love the notification feature for emails and text messages and the ability to respond on the watch. This is the bluetooth version so it cant perform the "number share" with your cell phone. Battery life is about 2 days max, wish it was better. I usually charge mine at night so dont use the sleep monitoring part of it. Tried charging it when in the shower but it doesnt charge fast enough in 30 minutes. I use it mainly for pulse monitoring and fitness tracking.

A little under 3 years of use and the back cover for the heartbeat sensor has come off from normal use. I've never swam with it or anything like that. I feel it should last much longer when I paid $260 for it. Mobile app is buggy as well but I dealt with it because as a watch it worked great.

I shopped around everywhere before I made a purchase because I wanted to Compare Quality and pricing. I looked at Best Buy Walmart Target an Amazon. Amazon had the best deal and the best quality! I am so happy that I went ahead and made this purchase through Amazon! It arrived before it was expected which I was very pleased with. All of the functions are wonderful I can talk text look at my calendar and my contacts and check my social media messages all on my wrist. I would highly recommend you purchase one of these if you are a busy person like I am it makes my life alot easy to not be pulling out my phone while at work or on the go! It fits perfectly and I also purchased interchangeable bands so that u can change my style when I get the urge.

The Samsung Galaxy watch 42mm is a great watch for fitness and style. It works pretty good at tracking actual physical movement so the readings are on point. The apps are easy to use and for the most part customizable in arranging apps to your preferences. I not a fan of all the options for faces it has but it gives you a basic four, you change colors and small details.
