The battery life would be the my biggest complain on this watch, it lasts about 2 days sometimes a day and half depending on the use. Also the rim of the watch is easily scratch, so if you're job involves a lot of moving or hands on I would take it in consideration.

I had my eye on this for a while. Its presentation is nice and the build quality is top notch.
I own an iPhone and the watch certainly works with the iPhone but in a limited capacity. The Galaxy app offers very limited accessibility to features on the phone where the app on a Samsung device offers much much more.
The App Store is a hot mess. While searching directly for a particular app the App Store would fail to find it, however that same app could be found by scrolling through the App Store.
WiFi connectivity is shoddy at best. The Auto WiFi feature would never switch from a Bluetooth connection to WiFi, you have to completely disable Bluetooth on your phone to force the watch to connect to WiFi (for faster downloads).
When you turned Bluetooth back on, the watch would not connect again without you disabling the auto WiFi connection.
Another huge disappointment is that Samsung Galaxy only works within its own ecosystem- exactly what Apple products tend to do. You cannot control your Google Home through this watch. You can use Google Assistant to control SmartThings, but no google devices are available to connect to SmartThings.
This product has so much potential but fails to live up to it.

Forget the original review.  This watch has, over time, been extraordinarily unreliable.  At least once a week it drains in only a few hours, and gets very hot.  Something is running in the background and I can't find out what.  I have made no tweaks to the watch other than changing the face.  Lately it has gone one step further.  It loses its face, loses its settings, will not reconnect to the phone, basically requires a power down and back up.  That does fix it, IF you can get the power down icon to work -- and it doesn't always work.  But by then it is down to 40% charge so you can't finish the day with it.  I have searched all tech documents for solutions and have found none.  Finally, today, when I could not even see the time on the thing, I removed the special steel mesh band I put on (which is very nice) and did another reboot of the watch.  With my 16 ounce claw hammer.  I'll say this -- I could only smash the crystal.  The case survived all my attempts to reboot it.  But, it is now thoroughly dead and in the bottom of the trash can.  This is not the first watch I have linked to the Galaxy phone.  Every other one had issues as well.  I don't think Samsung phones, and I like them, have got the techie stuff worked out yet for dealing with watches.  As much as I loathe and despise Apple products (I am a retired I.T. Director and software engineer, BTW) I have to admit that my wife's Apple watch and her iPhone do work together.  But I will go back to my nice Bulova quartz watch.  At least I'll be able to see the frickin' time!  My attempts to have a Dick Tracy watch are over.  This watch should get zero stars.

Bought the watch for my husband and we noticed upon opening the box that the outside was in spanish. Watch is fine, perfect condition but when uploading all the information we noticed that it did not have Samsung pay. A small minor thing that you can go without. Well I took the risk and sent it back to order another one to see if it was specifically that watch or if they all came that way. 2nd watch came in same thing. International version with a spanish box and no Samsung pay. Finally gave up and accepted fate with the watch, a couple of days later Samsung pay pops up. Watch hasn’t given him any issues since purchase.

I have been using this watch for a week and I love the features. The 42mm size is perfect for my wrists and it doesn't look like a smart watch because it is not real bulky. Even the smaller size it still is easy to read. It works great with my Samsung S9 smart phone and the Samsung wear app on my phone makes setting up and changing settings through the phone very easy. Battery life seems to be fine, used it a lot yesterday and when I took it off last night to charge it was only down to 65%, so it should work fine for at least two days. The only negative is the silicon band that comes with the watch is OK for sport use but I wanted a better looking band so I purchased a leather band for $15 on Amazon that looks great and fit perfect.

...definitely consider this one!  I got the smaller model (42mm) on sale.
That being said, the sale price does not sway my review in the least.
I've used this daily for over 3 months and I absolutely love this thing.  I've owned 1 other smartwatch in the past, but it was too far removed from this current generation to compare. The display is plenty bright.  The battery life is 2 days or more.  Side note:  The display settings will need to be adjusted; brightness and auto-off. Accuracy of steps is top-tier.  The GPS location works within < 5m in my testing.
There is a whole array of workouts that can be selected.  You can even select an intensity for some and it will adjust accordingly if you decide you want to go HAM on your workout.  Highly recommended!

I love this watch,I use mainly to control my headphones volume,getting notifications while in class is quite handy. I dont really use the fitness apps since I find that it drains the battery too much for my liking. Overall I think its more of a utility watch than a smart watch, the only thing thats really holding it back is the battery life, its adequate but goes down really fast if fidget with it too much I.e watching a quick how to youtube video on it but as a watch that has a few tricks up its sleeve its a 5/5 for me.Physically the watch is quite heavy which is a good thing since makes it feel sturdy, appearance wise it looks better on the pictures tbh,I guess I just need some aftermarket straps and bezels to spruce it up.

This smartwatch is by far the best I have ever used, I have the galaxy s9 and this works perfectly with it. The heart rate is accurate, the battery is great even though I got the 42mm version it could last me 2-3 days, it looks great, and you can customize it any way you want, it is extremely durable and is much better than i thought it was.  And a tip, if the bezel looks scratched take a wet rag and wipe it and it will most likely go away and look new again. Another tip, if it starts to be slow and lag quite a bit then just hold the home button and turn it off.  I wear this watch every day and use it all the time, and I still get compliments from people about it.  If your thinking about getting this watch, GET IT it is worth the money.

I resisted buying a smart watch for a long time. But when I saw the features on this watch, I decided to give it a try. Glad I did! The watch allows me to see who is emailing and texting me, so that I don't have to pull out my phone.  I can also text simple replies. If in blue tooth range, you can talk on the phone with it too. That happened to me the other day. I was in the backyard and had forgotten to bring my phone. Because of the watch, I didn't miss an important call. I like the watch face I use because it has the date, time, temperature, and battery life remaining. I would say the battery has 2 days, max, before needing recharging. It has a feature that puts it to sleep at night so the incoming texts and emails don't interfere with sleep. I am most pleased.

I got one about a year ago and loved it so much that I got him one, too. He's all tech crazy so I knew he'd like it and he does. I am not tech crazy but my kids and I love how I never miss their messages or calls any longer. It's really easy to use and does like everything imaginable. I can actually answer the phone using my watch! I'm like Dick Tracy or something. It knows when I'm doing some fitness thing and tracks me and tells me how I'm doing. I don't wear it to bed because I don't care about how I'm sleeping. It charges nicely and it lasts all day. It's kind of pretty but even if it's not elegant-looking, it's cool. So I'm cool now.

If you haven't bought one of these watches yet, you better get on it! This watch is very useful, reliable, classy and worth every penny! And for this like New Used version for $60? It's a no brainer! Very happy with this purchase. Came looking new and flawless, charger, charging cord and a hang on watch charger. If you haven't bought one yet after reading this you are trippn lol ?? ?? ??
La bateria no dura mucho, Maximo dos dias.

Lets be honest, those reviews you see on youtube do not apply to everyone. I use this watch to see and reply to short texts to my friends and group chat the battery life is great for one day then i take it off before i sleep and charge it or you can sleep with it. But only do that if you can spare 2-3hrs before you head out again so it can charge up but tbh i don't need to track my sleep. Its simple its easy but i do wish i had a watch face that showed 24hr format and was also analog for astetics but i digress for what it can do its grest but i do think the bigger watch face is better cuz it is kinda small but its still nice

Since I have other Samsung devices that I love, it was only logical to get the Samsung Watch.  Mine is not the one with Lte access.  The enhanced Health apps are great; steps, exorcise, heart, diet, and running can be tracked and managed. There are many other apps and widgets available to add to you watch that connect with your phone via Bluetooth including the standards: calls, calendar, weather, and many many more.  It does require that you keep your phone within BT range for some functions. I strongly recommend this watch for anyone with Samsung or android phones.  It does have an apple function but I don't know how that works.

The watch works perfectly. I would give it a 5 star rating but the charger that comes with it is junk. It lights up but never charges the watch. Have to share a charger with my wife until I find a new one I like.

I bought this after getting a cheap $40 smart watch just to see if I needed all those extra services a smart watch can provide. I've owned fitbit charge 2 and 3 for several years before deciding to switch to a smart watch. The convenience of being able to ping your phone to locate it was what really hooked me. After a couple weeks of owning the product I had to get a good smart watch, and I really love all the features of the Galaxy Watch. One big complaint though, is after several years of owning different watches with all kinds of different bands, the band this watch originally came with gave me welt like sores on my wrists. I tried switching hands, loosening the band, moving it up and down on my wrist, but after wearing it in place for more than an hour, my sking begins to burn. First two photos attached is my left hand, a couple hours after removing the band after wearing it for one work shift (the welt on the first pic originally had yellow in the middle) third photo is a couple weeks after I switched hands, the skin is dry and flakey. Again, I've had multiple different watches of varying brilliance, with multiple different rubber bands, and this is the first time I've had a reaction this severe.

When I saw the smaller size, I thought "Oh, this is the same size as the Gear S2 classic", which also has a 42mm screen. Unfortunately, the outer ring is larger, and more importantly, the watch is around 30% thicker. As a guy with small wrists, this thing looks huge on my wrist, and I'd especially prefer if it were thinner. Make it 40% thinner and less bezel and I'd upgrade immediately. The battery life does seem to be better, perhaps by around 30%. That's definitely something to consider upgrading for. The rest of the features are mostly the same in terms of things I care about, although I'm still poking around. But most likely I'm going to end up returning this and keeping my Gear S2 classic for a little while longer.

It does everything I would ask it to. The apps are simple, easy and complete. The processing does well and the ease of access is on point. My only complaints are that the battery doesn't last long. It is doing a lot of things and I can imagine it's hard to make a battery this small that will last, but it lasts 2-3 days if I don't use it much and 1-2 if i am actively using it. That and the Alti-Barometer doesn't always seem accurate. Not the biggest issue but those two are why it's 4 stars and not 5. Great watch!

The watch is a little bigger than expected. After wearing all day today, I am getting used to it.  So far, I am pleased with my purchase. I believe I will replace the existing "rubber" watch band with one of the after market fashion watch bands so that i can make the watch look a little more "feminine" and a little less "sporty".  Overall, i am still pleased with my purchase and would recommend this to others. I can't comment on Battery Life or Durability yet since i just got the watch yesterday.  I can say that it is very easy to set up and use. I also like the way the bands attach to the watch. I had a Gear Fit2.  The bands were continuously coming off.  This is why i upgraded to this watch. I don't think i will have that problem with this watch.

What can I say, I love my Samsung Galaxy SMartwatch.  The watch lasts me approximately 3-4 days before needing to be charged.  The apps are fine for what I need and use.  To be fair though the Android Wear is supposed to have more apps.  I love the twisty bezel to navigate all the functions.  It is one of the reasons I bought this version instead of the Galaxy Active.  It has all the fitness tracking I needs.  The voice recognition works very well for me as well.  I can narrate a text to someone pretty easily.  The one thing I haven't tried yet is the handwriting recognition.  It looks a bit difficult.  Be aware the screen is decent for a watch, but it can be hard to use the touchscreen, because of the size.  Especially if you have big old sausage fingers.  But that is where the twisting bezel comes in so handy.

But won't work with 3rd party apps like K9 mail and Chomp SMS. I hate the samsung factory installed apps, took an eternity to get it to receive notifications from 3rd party apps, after changing setting after setting I gave up, and then 2 days later it started to receive notifications from these apps, all on it's own. You can't go thru the archives if you miss the 3 second time window when the notificaiton pops up. The reply options are limited too, editing them is a royal PITA. It does control Pandora, which is one of the main reasons I bought it. The WiFi feature sucks battery life, so I just turned it off. All in all, better than the apple watches my friends have, but not exactly ideal. Needs work, hopefully they will push out an update soon

I've tried several watches.  I was about done and would have gone back to my old reliable Gear S1.  Well, I picked this one up and I am so happy with it.  I do use a lot of apps, change watch faces a lot, have alerts, incoming outgoing calls, text messages.  The battery lasts 1 1/2 days.  Again, I make it work.  I had a problem received my calls.  Did everything I knew.  A friend suggested we go to Best Buy and talk to the Samsung people.  Well, he figured it out.  I had the Blacklist on my phone and it was blocking all incoming calls.  Its works great.  When my phone is in the other room I can talk on my watch.  And I have the Bluetooth  version. It works perfectly with my LG Stylo 3 plus.  I highly recommend it. And its great that this is the latest and greatest.  So happy with this.  Thank you Samsung.

The Galaxy watch is really good. It's got great battery life, pretty good workout tracking, it's easy to use, has a beautiful screen, and it's fairly quick. However sometimes, and very rarely it slows down. Also, the bezel scratches very easily. After a week of use, (and I'm not very active and I don't use it while working on something) it's already obtained a few scratches. Some scratches buff out after a few rubs. Even though they're small it still bugs me. Otherwise the Galaxy watch is great. It has amazing battery life and that's one of the biggest highlights. If you need a good smartwatch with good battery life, get this watch. However if you are more clumsy or do a lot of hard physical work I would not recommend it to much, but you can always get protection. But in the end you should decide on what your lifestyle is and make your choice.

As soon as the note 10 was out I ditched my Apple phone.. Completely forgetting about how much I relied on my Apple watch. I kept it and went without what I needed bc the biggest thing I needed was HR since I have SVT.. Well I see a good deal and order a Fitbit health thinking I'm going to get everything I need, Only to realize it was a complete down grade from my Apple watch.. Until I came across this bad boy!!  I ordered all black, it arrived quickly, Bluetooth together beautifully and in
 no time I already downloaded what I needed and was able to answer calls/txt/emails without needing to carry my phone.. Being a mom of three special needs kiddos I'm constantly on the go and don't always have time to stop and check my phone!! This watch is it! If your like me and you switched from apple to Samsung, This is the equivalent to the apple watch!! You will love it hands down!! ????

I prefer the Galaxy Watch over my older Gear S3 because in the 42mm size it fits better on my wrist and I can wear it all day instead of just when working out.  The battery life easily lasts me a full day with about 40-50% to spare.  The rotating dial makes navigating the watch way easier and more intuitive to use than Wear OS watches. Unfortunately, despite years of complaints on various internet forums Samsung watches still lack basic podcast functionality.  There is still no TIzen app with native support for downloading podcasts directly to the watch.  Spotify comes closest and lets you download music onto the watch but not podcasts for some reason.  Instead in order to listen to podcasts while working out without your phone you have to go through a convoluted workaround which involves saving podcasts to the music folder of your phone then manually copying files on your phone or restarting your phone in order to get the Galaxy Wearable app to see new files that can then be transferred.  You also have to use an app like Pocketcasts which has an option to save podcasts in a format other apps can read. If you have an Android phone Samsung watches are still significantly better than Wear OS in terms of design and ease of use, but still held back by the lack of apps for Tizen and Samsung refusing for some reason to fill the gaps in the basic functionality they lack by making their own apps.

I wore the Gear S2 for a couple of years and liked it but it had its drawbacks. First, the smaller bezel make it harder to navigate, second was the fact that it did not have the 'always on' option which I really like on this version so I can always see what time it is without needing to do any type of wrist movement.  Okay, so what I like about this watch are the following:
1) Its waterproof,  Yay!!  I was always scared of getting the S2 wet and having it die on me.
2) Larger bezel screen to make navigating easier
3) The battery seems to last longer, however since I have the Dislay options on high its hard to notice so far, but I think it will last at least 8-9 hours more than the S2.
4) The whole case and appearance make it look more durable and resistable to damage. Good work Samsung!
THS ITEM IS EVEN BETTER THAN I THOUGHT. IT CAN DO SO MUCH AND HAS SO MANY FREE WATCH FACES THAT LOOOK REAL COOL. BATTERY LIFE IS NOT TOO BAD

First, to set up a Samsung account has taken over an hour of typing the same thing in over and over again. And it's always wrong. Worse than Apple! (which is bad about want pw every 3 clicks). It still doesn't come up right after I discovered that my phone was substituting a French accented character for a capital C and all other caps in the pw. Not Samsung's fault. BUT no way to visualize what the pw you've just typed was actually seen as. Second, The temperature setting seems locked in to °C. So 21°C is what I see on the watch face I picked. Have not found a way to change this to °F, and have it stick. Several way to supposedly change it, but none stick. Third, I want the face to go off after 10 seconds or so and then wake up when I twist my wrist or move my arm. I do no want to have to use my other hand to tap something. I keep making the change, but it doesn't stick...possibly a result of the password crap mentioned above. At this point I'm 1) kinda liking the thing. 2) Almost ready to take a ball pein hammer to it and toss it in the junk pile. and 3) why can't Samsung get the software right? Damn. My Samsung microwave works, so does my Samsung laundry set and my Samsung refrigerator. Not only that, but this is obviously an old (obsolete) version of the device what does it have us installing software for newer devices that crash before they complete (yes!). Grrr!

I like the watch, but not enough to have it be my sole watch for my new Android phone. The sleep tracking is not good, and I have tried tightening the watch one notch past where it is comfortable on my wrist. It sometimes thinks I am asleep while I am watching TV, and sometimes thinks I am awake for an hour in the middle of the night when I am asleep. The watchband is not large. My wrists are not large and I am on the 3rd-to-last notch. But it feels comfortable. I am ambivalent about Tyzen, but apparently it is better than WearOS. I'm coming from having an iPhone and an Apple Watch. It is not on par with an Apple Watch, but reviews say that no Android Watch is. So, it does it's job fine, except for the sleep tracking. On the plus side, it looks good, the GPS and step-tracking is great, battery lasts longer than I expected after reading reviews, and it's lightweight.

I bought this because I wanted  a smartwatch to track my steps, sleep and just in general to view incoming texts and stuff. That part it handled well, although the heart rate monitering could be better. Durability wise its amazing!! Buttons are clicky, strap is good, and you could always buy a screen protector for a few bucks if youre scared of scratching it. Although the rotating bezel has gotten loose a bit and Lowkey see that as an issue the more I use it down the line.. OS is very good if you use a samsung, although the app selection is very poor, I hope it gets better. Google maps isnt available and if you want use gps you have to buy an app and install it on your phone aswell. Theres spotify, tidal and stuff but basically it. Battery is amazing, im getting 1.5 to 2 days without a charge. If the OS was improved and the bezel didnt get loose after aome time it definitely would be the best smartwatch

I waited for months for this watch expecting something to actually compete with iwatch on fitness and smart watch capabilities.  Nope.  The main reason I would wear this over a nice analog watch is for fitness.  Its heart rate monitoring is terrible.  I have it set to constant auto monitoring but it only does it when I'm not moving, about once an hour at best.  It never works when I'm actually moving or exercising.  When I attempt to do a force measure when working out it gives an error every time about clean sensor.  If I'm sweating at all it will not work, kinda defeats the purpose. My ancient fitbit HR did 10x better on heart monitoring and it knew when I was working out even without logging it. This galaxy watch doesn't even know when I try to log it.  It just uses my heart rate from earlier in day and thinks I've done a few steps. I've tried everything short of shaving my arm hair to improve it.  I'm throwing in the towel.  It's pointless as a fitness watch, especially if you are doing any calorie counting like myfitnesspal. It's a decent smart watch but lacks a way to type using hand drawn characters like iwatch, so unless a canned response works or you can use voice, you can't respond on watch. The battery life is no where near what is advertised. I have to charge mine daily.  The only thing it does amazingly well is track sleep but if you wear it at night it will not last but a day on power. It does keep me off my phone and informed during meetings and court without drawing any attention, but it's pointless without reliable fitness tracking.  I'm not sold yet on the my fitness health app from Samsung either. UPDATE: After a few program updates nothing has changed.  If anything it's worse. Sometimes when I look at the heart rate readings I see they are from 2 days ago.  I cannot stress enough, do not buy this for fitness, buy it for smart watch features only.  I wish I could have returned this watch but by the time I figured out how bad it was as a fitness watch the return window closed.  I love love Samsung products (phones, tv's, tablets, etc) but hate to say it, this is the biggest Samsung disappointment ever (and I used to have the exploding Note 7).  I may try Garmin or give up and get an iPhone just for iWatch.

I'm not necessarily a super user of this product. I feel like I've bought a Ferrari to drive around in residential zones. I mainly bought it for the interchangeable interfaces because I'm a sucker for the fallout pip boy interface.  The heartbeat sensor seems to be more accurate than my previous Fitbit watch and the stress widget is a cool feature.
Pros: amazing customizability. the bezel dial to change which widget you're on is awesome, and if you use it just as a watch the battery is a champion.
Cons: To use the full utility of it (location, messaging, heartbeat sensor, etc) I have to charge the watch once a day. You may get two days out of it at best. also, verizon message+ doesn't seem to send notifications, so I had to switch to the android default messanger app in order to get message notifications. that's more on verizon though, rather than the galaxy watch I think.
Overall, I genuinely enjoy my purchase. I switch out which watch face I use a couple times a week, just because I can. It's inspired me to be more healthy. Yup. good times :-)

I am two years into owning this watch. I use it purely as a watch and a remote control for audio books via audible and YouTube. Changing the face when you get bored of one is like getting a new watch each time. In two years I'm on my 3rd strap, a leather strap with a much nicer feel than the silicone.  The battery is still going strong, I wear it all day at work and throw it on the charger when I get home and it's never below 80%.

I've been sceptical a long time on whether smart watches were really worth it; I already have a $800 phone, so why do I need this? Part of why I bought this was to help motivate me to lose weight after my mom said I had gained a few lbs. It tracks steps accurately, gives you reminders to move if you've been idle for an hour, will automatically detect if you've been walking or running as a workout, and a lot more. I chose this over a Fitbit because I feel the quality of the products has gone down and I really like having all the data at a glance. Of course, everything else about it is great. I love being able to control my music through the watch, glancing at who is calling or texting me while I'm out on the greenway, and customizing the watch face (I recommend the Facer app). The only con I can think of is why is the 42mm not available in silver? I bought a silver shield to cover mine so it looks exactly like the 46mm silver, but still... Come on Samsung, not every girl likes rose gold!

I've owned the Huawei watch 1 for several years so up until this point had nothing to compare it to. I thought that watch was great with good battery and quick response. Now that I've tried the Galaxy watch I realize how much better things have gotten. When always on is turned off I finish the day around 80% battery. That up at 5:30am and to bed by 111:00. I have the 42 mm version that has a smaller battery. With the Huawei watch I'd get maybe a day. I really did not want to turn off the always on because on the Huawei I had to shake my hand to get it to turn the display back on. Not so with the Galaxy. The screen activates every time. I was also concerned about lack of Google Wear OS. That hasn't been an issue at all. Granted I use this watch to monitor steps, sleep, tell time, and look cool. The waterproof feature was a big seller to me as well. And the readability outdoors blows the Huawei out of the water. I am seriously enjoying this watch. Couple that will the cool dial interface and you got a winner in my book.
It was delivered on time and works perfect. It's worth every dollar. I definitely will get another one.

I love this watch it's fast and effective a few things I don't like are:
1) I cannot respond to a text message I have to actively go into my contacts, find the contact and then select them and choose to send a new message.
2) The battery is at 40 something percent by the end of my clinical day, I do have a fancy watch face I downloaded (it's animated) but I don't have "always on" on. Those are my main complaints, however, I do not mind charging my watch every night, I do not use it to track sleep. I love that I can anser calls and the mic is loud enough for me.  it's odd but if it's not connected to my phone (ie I'm too far away from my phone) I can't answer calls but I can respond to the call with a text message...
It has made it so I can have my phone close to me but not seen, it is a seriously awesome piece of tech and I'm sure everyone has their pros and cons but I'm very happy with this watch!

This thing! So I will get the bad out of the way, it relies to much on the phone to give you information it is more an alert system for apps rather than fully functional on the watch. With that said, I love the damn thing! I am a DevOps Engineer and so I depend on things I let into my space to be functional and useful with as little complication as possible. I can have up to 5 meetings per day and this smartwatch has assisted me on getting to each of these on time, improving my time management and priority management. It has also motivated on my endeavors to get away from the screen and get up and move. I average about 2 miles a day at work walking around and thought that was good enough, now I am up between 7 and 9 miles per day walking away from my work is as important as the work itself. Overall I am very happy with it especially the spotify app screen. I should have gone with the larger one but oh well. I also just preordered the Note10+ which will make this function much better over the Note 8 I am currently using.

I tried 2 less expensive types of smartwatches and found them to be ok and also a bit quirky.  I then decided to go with the Galaxy watch.  I am impressed with the many capabilities this watch has.  I can receive text messages and calls without going for my smart phone.  You can answer and talk through the watch (kind of like Dick Tracy) some of you will know what I mean.  I am pleased with the performance and reliablility of this watch.  I first loaded up too many apps and widgets that I thought were useful, but soon found that I had not used them and it did reduce the battery life with all that running in the background.  I can get about 2 days without recharging.  The BP monitor, step counter, sleep monitor, reminders and calendar are really useful for me.  Be sure to buy one that has the U.S. warranty in case you have a problem.

For a refurbished item it's a worthwhile  expenses. Watchband is a little on the cheapish side,but  seems to be holding up o.k.
Power button is a little finicky but usable.

The rotating bezel is a joy to use on this watch. The implementation feels natural, and I wish all smart watches would use something similar. The clicks feel satisfying, and TizenOS takes advantage of the bezel too. The size is great, and 42mm fits my wrist perfectly. Although it still is a thick watch, every smart watch is going to be relatively thick compared to normal watches as well. I think you'd have to have a very large wrist to warrant the 46mm (or you might want the bigger screen/battery). I don't find the shortage of third-party apps in TizenOS to be restrictive. I mostly use the watch to track my runs, and view notifications without needing to access my phone. I can't imagine what else I would need. The battery life is okay. I get about 1 full day with my current setup: brightness at 2, always on display, location off, heart-rate every 10 minutes. I put the watch on before bed, then charge it the evening of the next day (~16-20 hours of use). I think this is currently the best smart watch out there for Android phones. Even better if you have a Samsung phone. It's almost a no-brainer if you have a Samsung phone already. I would highly recommend this watch!

If you're looking for an overpriced piece of of junk that tells you the time and counts your steps, then this is the watch for you! Other highlights...frequently looses connection with my phone despite being 10ft away. Randomly answers phone calls simultaneously along with my phone causing a confusing echo resulting in the other person hanging up. Sometimes notifies me of texts....sometimes doesn't. Basically it worked well for a short time and now it's basically a watch that counts steps and needs to be rebooted more and more frequently as time goes on. Oh...and Bluetooth is sometimes on and sometimes it discretely turns off on its own and you don't realize it for a day or 2 while you're wondering why this $200 weight on your wrist doesn't seem to be doing anything that is supposed to beyond telling time. Only had this for like 6 months and after the first 3 months or so, it became an unreliable piece of junk.

I came from a galaxy gear s2, unfortunately i lost the watch one day and decided to get this new version. This watch is what the s2 is but better, faster, and actually more usefull because of the gps and the speaker on it. What i loved about the s2 is that it was handy; i used the timer, the alarm, the heart rate monitor, back/next for music, basically little things/apps that were right there conveniently on my wrist. Now on this new version The gps on it can track my location and the speaker can announce information during my runs; handy stuff. Even though the apps on the appstore are 90% useless, the ones that are useful are AMAZING. To me a smartwatch is 1st a watch and second a piece of gear that SUPPLEMENTS your phone. I dont need to play games on my watch, look at pictures, watch youtube, and surf the internet from my watch; to me thats stupid. What i do need are little apps that help me get through the day rather than pulling out my phone which would actually be more time consuming; this watch is GREAT at doing that. If you want a handy piece of gear that can supplement your phone, this watch is awesome

The Watch is incredibly well built. The bezel is really awesome and the system is way ahead of Wear OS.
But the battery life is not that great. I use the watch normally, with Always On (because it's a watch, its only natural that it always shows the time) but with WiFi off, NFC off, a lot of automatic sensors turned off and still it lasts only for a day... actually, less than that. I start using it at 7:30 and when its 23:00 the battery is already at less than 15%. Also, the music controller on the exercise screen of the Samsung Health app doesn't work (but its a software bug, easy to repair). The Spotify app (in Remote mode, using connected to smartphone) is not working at the moment of this review too (but its also just a software issue). Oooh, and don't expect to have a lot of beautiful watch faces on your watch unless you're willing to pay for them. The great majority of the faces that are actually cool or pretty are paid. Still, there's a lot of free ones too, but in a general way, they aren't that good. Apart from those issues, the Watch is what I expected: a great amount of quality in one product.
Me agrado que se ve muy bien. La correa un poco pequeña. La carga dura menos de lo indicado pero nada grave. Esta funcional y buen precio

Ok first of all I have used several kinds of Fitbit’s and I can say I’d order this watch over and over again compared to any of them!! I absolutely love this watch, and love all the free faces, plus the ease of setting this up. I couldn’t ask for more out of a smartwatch, and you can download all kinds of apps and goodies for it, so don’t let the negative reviews get to your head, they are nit-picking at anything to complain about. Like I said, I’d definitely buy it again, and would recommend to anyone on the market for a true smartwatch that works flawlessly and runs quickly!!! And you CAN easily use WiFi and Bluetooth at the same time lol u have to use WiFi always on mode and then after setting it up you can switch back to auto mode..Wake up mode (when you move your wrist) CAN be adjusted where it is hard to get it to work, and it works flawlessly on mine,it also DOES give accurate heart rates, I own a couple different Fitbit that don’t have any more accurate than this, and my Bluetooth never randomly quits, sounds like people are trying to blame all their other problems on this watch and not the other stuff they have come to rely on (aka Fitbit) loI I love the crybabies that cant work technology and are making complaints and giving negative reviews..
Maybe before writing a negative review you should look up how to do it or something... or maybe if you can’t work technology, don’t blame the watch because you can’t figure out certain features and therefore give it a bad review (aka fake review) because you can’t work your technology or read directions!!!!

My Versa's battery stopped holding a charge after two years, and after reading reviews I learned that is a thing with those watches, so even though I was very happy with that watch I decided to try something different. My wife has a Galaxy Active, which led me to this watch.  After a couple of weeks, I like the Galaxy Watch. It's bulkier than the Versa, the battery takes longer to charge and doesn't last as long (this latter has been a disappointment after reading the reviews), but the big screen is easier to read and I think I will like the rotating bezel, which, if nothing else, acts as a bit of a protection for the screen ... and that's a good thing because given its larger size I have been bumping it into everything (and to think I was contemplating the 46mm!)  It has been staying reliably connected to my phone (S8), which is good because notifications is one of the primary reasons I wear a watch these days. All in all, I'm pleased ... I'll keep tweaking settings trying to get to 4 days of battery life, and I'm hoping that my Galaxy Watch lasts longer than 2 years!

I bought this to replace my GearFit2 Pro. I'm very surprised at how much I love it. I've always been the type of person that was like "I can just take my phone out of my pocket and read a notification, or see who is calling." Well that mindset changed a lot for me when I got the GearFit2 Pro to replace a Sony SmartBand I had. Now that I have the Galaxy Watch I'm even more of a fan of having the notifications on my wrist. I can even take a call from my wrist instead of having to pull my phone out. It honestly makes life a little easier. The battery life on mine is pretty good considering I have heart rate and stress monitoring on continuously. It last me about 2 full days. I have a screen protector on my and I still haven't had to replace that. It doesn't seem to get beat up as much as you would think it would on your wrist. I haven't had any issues with the buttons or the rotating bezel. I shower with it daily (unless it's on the charger). I haven't had any issues with it getting laggy or any other common issues I've heard about. The step tracking seems to be on par with any other tracker I've used. The floor tracking however is far from perfect. I usually don't trust it by any means. I replaced my stock band with a different band. It was easy and quick. Overall I would recommend this smart watch. I'm even of thinking about buying a second for my fiance.

For a smaller guy as myself (5'9") I find the 42mm a great fit. The wake up gesture works great and I find the activity tracking works very well. I am not sleep expert, but the watch does seem to know exactly when I go to sleep and wake up. Not sure if I will even care in the coming weeks. but pretty neat at the moment. However, I have a few minor issues I don't like and perhaps I will overcome them as I get more familiar with the watch. Text messages
I have a Samsung Galaxy S8 and if I read my text messages on my watch, my phone does not mark the message as ready. I am using Google messages, so maybe its not compatible. But in my 2015 car I can read the message on the infotainment center and it gets acknowledged. Its not too big of a deal, but in my opinion, it kinda of defeats the purpose of using your watch. Notifications
I have disabled most of the notifications I don't want to see. But I have not figured out how to disable the daily briefings, or when my phone is out of range (it vibrates) or some various other apps on the phone. Goodnight mode
I love the goodnight mode feature. It seems to recognize when its getting close to bedtime, giving you the option to enable or suspend. But it does not always recognize when I get up. I find half the time I have to turn it off. Battery life
I know the 42 has the smaller battery, but I am a little disappointed with the life so far. I have gotten close to two days of use before needing to recharge. My expectation was 3 full days. Of course I find myself messing with it often. Hopefully, the life will improve as I scale back my usage.

This watch is amazing, I have never had a watch before so this is my first but you can do so much with it. Measure your stress levels quite accurately, be able to see how long/well you sleep, calories, steps, and lots lots more in regards to health/calories/fitness. I was pleasantly surprised by the ease of navigating throughout the watch and it is quite nice to have it connected with my phone so when I get a text it pops up on my watch and I can quickly see who sent what and reply if needed. There are SO many faces available that you can choose from, I saw one from Fallout and it looked pretty awesome so I used that but there are literally hundreds of them. In terms of battery life it is not that great around two days maximum, but that's not necessarily bad unless you are constantly using your watch for fitness which tends to drain the battery quite fast. On an average of use it has gone from 100 to 70% with me, so technically speaking if you don't plan on using this so much for fitness tracking it can last up to 3 days without charging. The Samsung Pay feature is great as well I have both of my cards on there and if I need to pay I just put my wrist next to the credit card scanner machine and press pay. You can also download/play music on it or control the music on your phone, useful is you have headphones on and don't want to take your phone out and just scroll through quickly on your watch to the wanted song. All in all, definitely worth it this watch is awesome.

So I liked almost everything about this watch and it amazed me in many different ways like the customization and how high tech it is. you can do nearly everything you can on your phone on this watch except the obvious stuff like watch movies. I absolutely loved how it looks and it feels very solid, definitely very high quality. the clicking of the rotating navigation piece is super satisfying too. Overall its been a wonderful experience except 1 small thing... It is heavy! I know that sounds weird because it is just a watch how heavy can it be?, right? well it felt like i had a small weight strapped to my wrist all day and it actually began to hurt wearing it all the time. Now I'm sure i could continue wearing it an my muscles will adapt but honestly I'd rather wait for a lighter version in the future. So that being said if you are used to having something on your wrist all the time I definitely highly recommend this watch especially if you have a Samsung Galaxy phone. the battery was impressive for how much is going on in this little thing. it would last about 2 days and comes with a wireless charger that will get you 100% in about an hour. Also i have to mention the packaging for this was very nice, it was nice and compact and everything in the box was nice and tight. they definitely made sure these watches are getting to their new owners without problems, that's always nice to see.  great watch just not for me.

This watch growth on me. First day I wanted to give it 3 stars, second day I started to kind of like it, and from third day I am mostly loving it. Pros:
* First non-Apple non-gigantic smartwatch that fits OK on my somewhat small wrist.
* Easy to disable all unnecessary notifications and make the watch unintrusive
* User interface seems very optimized. You don't need to do many clicks to get where you need. For me 95% of my needs are met on two screens - the watch face and swipe to the right for weather. That's it.
* Love the choice of watch faces and that you can fit time, fitness and weather (with some limitations) on one screen
* Fitness functions seem to work fine. Nice to be able to see your your speed and route on the map when you bike. Neutral
* Battery lasts reliably two days. It can probably do 2.5 days total. Kind of same as the 1st gen Apple watch I had some years back. Cons / to improve:
* Making it thinner would be nice. It is still a brick on your hand. Although for the fairness Samsung made it fairly elegant, but didn't do as good of a job of hiding thickness as apple did.
* Custom watch faces do not seem to include weather. I suspect some API limitations making weather unavailable to 3rd party developers.
* I wish some watch faces included not just current temperature, but also high and low for the day.
* Bixby speaks in a ridiculous computer voice, which no longer feels normal in the age of Alexa, Siri and Google Assistant, but is otherwise functional (e.g. I found it to be the simplest way to start timer when I do meditation). I hope many further improvements will come via software updates.

I do love my watch.
Like I do every day, I took it off to charge it over night
Next morning when I took it off the charger I noticed the screen is broken (see picture).
Thought it was weird,how can I just break like that,but I figured just a malfunction screen,it happens.
So I went online @ Samsung.com since I registered it 6 month ago after I recieved it.
Good news!! Its under warranty(what I assumed since it literally just went bad over night)Yay!!
Filled out the online form included the picture.
24h later a customer representative called me,gave me via email the shipping instructions.
Shipped it off. Everything went smoothly, even customer service was great.
A week later I get a email saying I need to pay approximately 150$??.
I called them right away,asking why do I need to pay if it's under warranty.
She said because of water damage/ abuse it doesn't fall under warranty.
Water damage??? This watch is supposed to be waterproof!!! Even tho it didn't got in contact with water(I always took it off for showers and such).
So I argued with her for a minute about it and after I noticed I wouldn't win this battle I gave in and paid since it's just a fraction of the cost of a new one.
I'm just very upset that they claim it was "water damage/ abuse",pretty much my fault... what was not....I just charged it.
I personally think it's a way for them to get away not to pay for it.
I talked to a couple friends about that issue, they own a apple watch....2 of them had similar issues and apple did the same to them.
Its frustrating because I love my watch.
You can clearly see in the picture that the screen has no crack ,that this was a faulty screen.
Samsung you need to do a better job,take care of your customers!!
Had to sent the first watch back due to it being locked. They were understanding & offered to replace it. Sent it back & recieve my replacement today. Works great. Thanks

I bought my first Android smartphone in 2009, the MyTouch 3G.  It was the second android to hit the main market.  It never should have. The technology was too immature.  It lacked the power to run all of the functionality it was supposed to have.  Often, when I would receive a phone call, the phone was SO laggy that the call would go to voicemail before the phone could let me answer it.  It was... gimmicky.  A smartphone, yes, but not really all that smart. I feel similarly about the Galaxy Watch.  What does it really do besides be a smartwatch, by definition?  There were a few apps that were useful.  "Find my phone" was nice.  The apps for weather and such were also useful, but really not any easier than pulling out my phone.  I could send quick text responses, which was an upgrade over my previous wearable, a Fitbit Charge 2. It was slow.  It would lag when it was doing nothing, processing nothing.  I would pull down the menu to put it into sleep mode, and it would lag when I did that, and when I pressed the button for sleep mode.  Why was it lagging?  It wasn't doing anything!  It wasn't sending or receiving data.  It wasn't even opening an app.  It lagged because it was evidently underpowered for even the performance of its most basic task, showing a watch face. Battery life:  less than advertised.  If I let it run down to zero, it might last a day, a day and a few hours tops.  As it was, I would go to bed with it fully charged and it would easily run down to 78% overnight, on sleep mode.  And folks, let me tell you, I don't sleep long nights.  This, by the way, was with the setting on infrequent heart rate monitoring.  Speaking of heart rate monitoring, let's move on to my main reason for wanting a smart wearable, activity tracking. It was ok at this.  It would count steps fine, and would automatically detect when I was on a walk or doing something else it considered exercise for ten minutes or more.  The display of fitness data was pretty. It is garbage at tracking floors climbed.  I was lucky if it detected 1/4 of the floors climbed on any given day.  Samsung has been made aware of this, and thus far has basically shrugged its shoulders about it.  Sleep tracking was subpar.  Several nights, it failed to track sleep at all, and when it does track sleep, the data is very basic. In the end, it's less functional at the things I prioritize and basically is only good at looking pretty and being high maintenance.  That's right, the Galaxy watch was effectively like a bad girlfriend or boyfriend*. Anyway, I dumped it and instead bought the newer generation of my old fitbit, the Charge 3.  I now enjoy much better fitness tracking, dramatically superior battery life, and hey, the new fitbit can even send quick text responses, so now that's covered.  It was $130 cheaper and all I've really sacrificed is style points.

The lithium batteries at that time were not as good yet as they are today. A few months ago this watch started to keep the charge for shorter time. Few days ago it overheated at first and then completely died. It happened the same way years earlier than with the watch, when my Samsung smartphone not just overheated, but bloated when driving in the car and it was even dangerous. This watch just overheated and died. I do not recommend you to buy a used one.

I'm coming from OG Microsoft Band land, so have little to compare this to, honestly. Don't try to install Spotify. It will drain your battery within hours because it constantly runs in the background without even using it. Hang up a call? Auto play Spotify. Mess with anything audio? Opens Spotify! I was stoked about this feature, but Samsung/Spotify really need to step up their game. There's a little lag between receiving texts/calls and having the content show up on your watch, but overall this feature is about as good as I expected. Making and taking calls from my wrist is fantastic. Facebook messenger notifications do not show up. Battery life, after uninstalling Spotify and resetting the watch is actually darn good. I can run a third party sleep tracker all night, track my training for several hours, and it's only at about 60% thereafter. It sits a little funny on my tiny wrists. (5'4, 108lbs). I've tried right side up and upside down, but it's just weird- maybe that's me, though. A lot of times, turning my wrist to activate the watch face doesn't work... a lot of times it'll do it when I don't want it to. Little frustrating. Best bet is to forget set it to "always on" and very dim, or "always off", and press the home button to see it. Heart rate tracker seems to be fairly accurate, but the watch is always telling me to slide it further up my arm. If I put it any further up, it'd be at my elbow. I'm an acrobat and have decent sized forearm muscles, so keeping it in place is difficult and a little inhibiting. I've tried flipping it upside down, no dice. Sometimes it just drops your HR and fills in the blanks with guesses. GPS is hit or miss, but I'm in a rural area so take that with a grain of salt. I'd say if you're looking for a decent balance between smart/fitness, this is about what you can expect. Smart watches and fitness trackers alike still leave a bit to be desired in 2018, and it seems no one watch has it all down pat. *****ONE MONTH UPDATE*****
It's been a month now of daily use for sleep taking, weightlifting, running, yoga, and acrobatics practice. I've taken away two stars because the heartrate tracker is just awful and unreliable. I don't know if it's because of my forearm anatomy that I mentioned in my initial review or because Samsung just really needs to up their game. My skin in basically translucent, and I adjust the watch whenever it says I need to scoot it up my arm a bit further, yet still it simply is not capable of tracking my heartrate when I am in or above my target/vigorous/max zone. I've provided a picture of my data from yesterday's 5.5 mile trail run where you can clearly see that as soon as my HR was where I wanted it to be, the watch dropped it and lost it completely for nearly three entire remainder of my run. This means that the calories burned is inaccurate, and I don't have good info to go on to plan my next run. I came home with an exertion migraine, and although I'm not blaming that on the watch, it would have been nice to know that I was overdoing it a bit. This is REALLY frustrating, and I'm considering returning the watch at this point. I still have issues with the face waking up when I look at it, too, and don't want to set it to "always on".

I love the notification and calling features on this watch.  I dont have to pull out my phone to answer a text or to make a call i can see and answer them from my watch.  I can also make calls from the watch.  I have only used the watch for running so far and the metrics look good and I can control the music from my watch. The 42mm watch is large for my very tiny wrists but still comfortable.  I really like the rotating bezel to find apps etc.  My garmin 735xt was out for repair so i ordered this for the calling features but my first impression is that garmin is still better for tracking sports.  Also I like to do sprint tris and the samsung galaxy wont track a tri.  I also love that my 735xt battery lasts for 7 days or so.  The galaxy seems like I will need to charge it every night.  Its a much more attractive watch than the 735xt and i like the barometer and altimeter. I was considering the fenix 5s plus because it has maps and music but it is very pricey.  This watch has maps, but they come loaded with only a Korean gps location and so far I cant get it to load my location.  I was hoping to use this feature while biking and running but Im not sure this is possible. I swapped the band already because I really didnt like the one it came with. This watch comes in a 4g lte version.  I considered this so I could run without my phone, but decided against it since you need to pay another fee to your cellular provider to use it without your phone to make and receive calls.  I havent tried loading music on the phone yet but have used the watch to forward and pause tracks while running with i heart radio. I also loaded the navigation app that goes with Google maps.  That works so when you set a use google maps on your phone your watch navigates your route Update:. 9/12/18 One of the main reasons i decided on this watch is because I could answer calls on it while working without pulling out my phone.  This worked great until the last update, now my watch only buzzes and doesnt tell me who is calling and gives no options for answering.  Also I tried to use the find my car app and it doesnt seem to work.  The touch screen is lagging sometimes.  Also while working out it doesnt seem to read my hear rate.  Also I tried to reset the watch and I cant even do that.  I am seriously considering returning it even though I loved it for the first 2 weeks.
My husband loves it works great

It's a decent smart watch, but the only way you're going to get anywhere close to the advertised battery life is if you put a dark face on it, turn off always on display, and basically turn off all fitness tracking. I get about 3 days of battery with every fitness feature except the heart rate monitor turned off.
Now let's talk about the OS, IT'S AWFUL.  I don't know what Samsung was thinking, Tizen OS is the worst, glitchiest,  and most sluggish operating system i have ever seen. Especially the speak to text feature, 9/10 times it hears the wrong word, or if you speak too fast, it won't even type what you said.  I'm glad the new series 3, 4 and 5 are using google wear OS i hear instead of tizen. That's a step in the right direction, problem is, they made the batteries smaller in those watches instead of larger. So, you're sacrificing battery life to get a proper working operating system on the new watches. I paid 199 for this watch, which i don't think is worth it with how clunky the OS is. If you can get one for under 100 since this version is 4 gens old now, go for it,  the battery is a lot better on this version than the newer watches.

I've been wanting a smart watch for a while now and finally decided to pull the trigger.  My biggest criterion were that it had to be reasonably sized, reasonably priced, have GPS, and be able to have offline maps.  I really liked the look of the Gear S3 Frontier and the Galaxy watches (let's be real - the new 42mm Galaxy watch in black is basically the Frontier's little brother), and I LOVE the rotating bezel. I tried out both the S3 Frontier and the Galaxy watch and came to the following conclusions.
1) Look - the style of both watches are very similar (which you can see from the product photos).
2) Size - the 46mm Frontier watch is obviously larger than the 42mm Galaxy.  The watch band on the Frontier is thicker and has a slightly wider style that made it look larger than it actually is.  I ended up buying a smaller band similar to the style on the Galaxy to remedy this.  For me, the 42mm Galaxy wins on size.  The screen was only slightly smaller, but the watch as a whole was much smaller (as you can see from my comparison pictures).  The thickness of the two watches is about the same.
3) Rotating Bezel - I found the bezel on the Frontier was easier for me to use.  It's slightly taller than the one on the Galaxy, and the notches on the side are bigger.  The Galaxy bezel fit into the face of the watch a bit more smoothly, so you have to rotate it from the top of the watch, whereas on the Frontier you can rotate it from the side or top.
4) Navigation - navigation through the different widgets and apps was very intuitive on both watches.  You can use the bezel or touchscreen to move through items, and the two buttons on the side to select and navigate.
5) Maps - ultimately this was the item that tipped the scale in favor of the Frontier for me.  There's an app you can download called HERE WeGo which provides directions from your location to your destination.  Very similar to how Google Maps works.  However, it also supports an offline functionality where you can download maps of an area (state / province / etc.) so you have them available without being connected to your phone.  The downside to this is that it doesn't have a satellite or topographic view, but I tested it out locally and the trails I took were all on there.  So if I go hiking somewhere and get lost, I have a general idea of where I am - I can see it on the map.  When I tested HERE WeGo on the new Galaxy watch it doesn't function unless you're connected to the phone, because you can't download offline maps to the Galaxy.  I checked with their support team and they said they will consider it for the future (but that doesn't help me now). Ultimately I ended up keeping the S3 Frontier and returning the Galaxy.  The Galaxy won on size and waterproof rating, but I just couldn't justify spending almost double on the Galaxy when it wouldn't meet one of my biggest criterion (the offline maps).  It's no Suunto or Garmin or Casio, but for the price point it meets my needs as a GPS watch.

I'll very briefly state that I once owned a fitbit with a wristband that could not be removed and that it caused rashes on my wrist. I wore the Galaxy watch with the default band and it caused a similar effect. When it comes to negatives with the physical device, this is my only complaint. Luckily there are a myriad of choices for wristbands to aleviate this issue. Go wild! Now onto the stuff I liked. On my second day with the watch, (being the clumsy idiot I am) I walked in the house with my arms loose as normal as I have not worn a watch for many years, and I slammed my wrist into a door. Obviously this was cause for concern when I saw the scuffs all over the rotating part of the watch. To my surprise, it was the door that had suffered and not the watch! The paint cleaned right off and there was zero damage to the watch. Big points for being tough right off the bat. The rotating bezel is just plain fun to use to navigate to the different functions, even if you can just flick the screen to achieve the same result. Mine did show some slight lag here and there but it is not to the point where it just isn't working. After using it for a while you can just automatically turn it to what you want without even looking, like shifting gears in a car. As for the app that pairs with the watch, the usual samsung crap is included like samsung pay, but you at least have the option to keep it off the watch for the most part. As for the rest of the stuff on there, you'll get access to calls, texts, and even e-mails if you're using that specific email service (didn't see gmail but don't quote me on that) which as a first time and admittedly late adopter to the smartwatch era I found incredible. The speaker on the watch is loud and makes calls simple and easy to hear. I didn't even know the watch had a speaker when I bought it so that was a fun surprise. Through the wearable app you have the ability to reorganize all the apps on the watch as well as remove or add as you desire, and it's fairly simple to use so anyone willing to just read what's on the screen will be able to customize the layout to suit their needs best. For many I assume that the health features are the reason for the purchase, as that was my main draw for it. There's dozens upon dozens of exercises the watch can help keep track of, including even some weight lifting. It has a step counter, - of course - a heartrate monitor, stress tracker(?), sleep tracker, and has pretty much everything that the phone version of samsung health features in a compact package. If you do not have the watch connected to your phone, when you reconnect it'll synchronize all the data together so even if you had one device away from you charging, the other will count your steps for example and then bring that data to one spot when you reconnect. The sleep tracker caught me off guard with how spot on it seems to be with your sleep times. I kept watch on that for about a week and I think it'd be a valuable tool for those trying to maintain a consistent sleep schedule. Some people I saw complained that the heart rate monitor was draining their battery quickly, but you can set it to check only when you initiate that so keep it in mind. I'll typically get a full 4 days with it charged to max, but this is just everyday use without much heartrate monitor use or health tracking. It's about 3 days and a half when I do use it to track exercise, so it's still a pretty awesome battery life considering how much smaller it is compared to the larger watch model. There are many options for you to mess around with in order to optimize battery life, so just don't let the "heartrate monitor" reviewers scare you off about how long it lasts. There is much more that can be said about the device, but for those of us not too interested in having the latest model and just needing it for a little extra ease in life, I can fully recommend this watch. It certainly doesn't hurt that it's a nice looking piece, and with the seemingly endless options for wristbands and watch faces, no two watches ever have to look exactly the same.

I bought the smaller, 42mm, version of this watch and received it yesterday (4 days after ordering). FIRST IMPRESSION: The watch looks great and is actually the exact same size as the analog watch that I've worn for years, albeit a tad thicker. I was worried that the 46mm version would be too big on my wrist, and, based on how this one looks on my wrist, I was right. To give you an idea of how big my wrist is, this watch has two holes left on the band once worn at a comfortable tightness. (The watch also comes with another band that has more holes for a larger wrist). The rubber band that comes with the watch is minimalist and looks fine, but I wanted something a little more classy, so I ordered a brown leather band to spruce up the looks (it should be delivered next week). Also, you can see from my picture on the underside of the watch that it is super easy to switch bands using the little toggle switches. I like that this watch doesn't look like a smartwatch at first glance. It really does look like a regular analog watch. EASE OF USE:  I was able to jump right in and start using this watch with no issues. It took me about 45 minutes to set everything up, including downloading the apps for my phone, signing in to my accounts, and tweaking all of the settings to my liking. The rotating bezel makes it super easy to navigate around the menus, and the touchscreen is very responsive to swipes and taps. The screen looks great and is very clear and bright. I have my brightness set on 7, and it is perfect for being outside in the daylight or indoors. This 42mm version might be a tad too small of a screen for some, but it is just right for me. The battery took about an hour to fully charge, and it was on 25% when I received it, so I would guess 1 hour and 20 minutes to full charge from zero. DAY 1 BATTERY and USAGE IMPRESSIONS: I put the watch on at about 7 pm on day 1 and was messing with it most of the night, switching watch faces and exploring the options and tweaking settings. I then set it to Goodnight Mode (to turn off all notifications except alarm), and set it to track my sleep. The alarm vibrates and makes a sound. I'm not sure if the sound can be turned off...if so, I haven't figured out how. I'm a fairly heavy sleeper, and it was enough to wake me up. Also, the snooze option worked and was easy to do half-asleep. As I'm writing this, the watch has been on my wrist for about 19hrs, and it is at 72%. At this rate, I'll be able to get about 3 days of use, which is what the literature claims. TIZEN & APPS: I was worried that I wouldn't like the fact that the Tizen OS doesn't allow you to download 3rd party apps, and this IS a huge shortcoming for the watch. However, I have my phone on me all day, so there's really nothing I would want my watch to do that I wouldn't be fine with reaching into my pocket and pulling out my phone for. Anything else added to the watch (as far as apps) would be gimmicky and just extra. The main thing for me is that it DOES work with most third-party apps as far as notifications. My main concern was that I wouldn't be able to get text notifications because I use Textra for texting on my phone. But I was able to set the watch to get notifications from Textra, and when tested I was able to respond to the text using my watch. The Samsung app store is a joke, and 99% of the apps on there don't work at all. That was a huge disappointment. SPOTIFY NEGATIVE: I was excited to get to use Spotify on the watch with Bluetooth headphones. BUT, the Spotify streaming service only works on the watch if you have a Premium account, which I do not. So, there's that. PROS:
-Looks great, classy (with a better band), and looks just like an analog watch.
-Easy to use: The bezel, buttons, and menus all work together flawlessly.
-Easy-to-replace bands. Plus, you can find a ton of bands online for fairly cheap.
-Answering calls (and talking) is easy and clear and eliminates the need to pull your phone out (given that you're in an area where you can just talk aloud on speaker.)
-Samsung Health works great at tracking steps, calories, etc, and the app also offers a lot of options for exercise programs and workout ideas, which is great for someone like me who is moderately active and needs a little push and assistance to get moving. CONS:
-Tizen has limits as far as 3rd party app support, and the Samsung store is laughable, but you can still get notifications from most 3rd party apps.
-While there are lots of options for watch faces, there's only a small amount of free ones that are decent. Most of them will cost you $2-$4.
-Pricepoint is a little high. I was able to use my Health Savings Account card to purchase this watch due to having Type 1 Diabetes and getting my doctor to sign a paper saying the fitness aspect would help regulate my blood sugar, but if I wasn't able to do that I probably wouldn't have bought this watch because of the price.

I brought the smaller 42mm Galaxy watch in midnight black. My wrist is small and kind of narrow, the 42mm Galaxy watch fits perfectly.  I brought a black steel band for the watch but the band that came with the watch is so soft and light that I decided to use the watch with the standard black silicone band. The Galaxy watch is very light, I don't feel that I am wearing it. This watch can be use by itself or link by bluetooth to a android or an iOS smartphone.  I don't have a smartphone and the Galaxy watch app cannot be installed on a tablet, only a smartphone.  I try to install the Galaxy watch app on my Samsung Galaxy Tab S4 tablet, it would not install, a message said that the tablet is not an appropriate device. I install the software on the Galaxy watch standalone and connect it to my home network.  The Galaxy watch is working perfectly as a standalone smartwatch.  I will purchase a smartphone in the future but this smartwatch can be use without a smartphone but not using all of it's features. The 42mm Galaxy watch has approximately 2 - 3 days of charge before charging it again. The larger 46mm Galaxy watch has approximately 4 - 5 days of charge before having to place the watch on the charger. It will take approximately 2 hours to completely charge the Galaxy watch from 0 to 100%. I charge the Galaxy watch every morning while I am washing myself and getting dress. This is a feature rich and a very powerful smartwatch.  I had use a Garmin VIVOactive HR and a Fitbit Ionic smartwatch before purchasing the Samsung Galaxy watch. I notice that the price of the Galaxy watch is going down. Before buying a smartwatch,  cut out a 46mm circle out of cardboard and a 42mm circle,  place both on your wrist to see which size fits your wrist better.  The Samsung Galaxy Watch is one of the better smartwatch being sold. Goggle which smartwatch is the best or the better smartwatch being sold today. Samsung Galaxy Watch will be high on the list. I personal highly recommend the Samsung Galaxy Watch either the larger 46mm or the smaller 42mm size.

This is my first smartwatch, and I bought it more to test it out.  I really wasn't sure I was going to keep it, but after using it for about a month, I can say this will stay on my wrist daily.  The watch looks great.  I am glad I got the 42mm as the black on black is really sleek.  It makes my fiends iWatch look like a toy.  The screen is very clear and easy to see even outside.  I leave it set to brightness level of "6" and it adjusts for me when needed.  The watch faces are very cool, and there are literally thousands you can get, and many are free.  You can make this look like a fancy watch, a Casio, a gadget, tactical, and everything in between.  Really a fantastic looking watch. For battery life, I average 3 days.  My first two charges didn't last as long, and I was a little worried.  But now I get three days with room to spare.  I do not sleep with it.  I put in airplane mode at night.  It is on my wrist and in use for 12-18 hours a day.  I have Wifi off, and location off because my Note 9 handles all that through Bluetooth.  I only have it monitor my heartrate when I am doing an exercise.  I take calls on it regularly, check email and texts, and use it for fitness.  I would say I am a moderate user. I love the built in altimeter and barometer, and found them to be reasonably accurate.  I also found the step tracking to be fairly accurate as well, though it does miss some steps here and there.  Sometimes it is simply delayed.  Tizen OS is smooth and easy to use, but there are not a lot of apps yet in the Samsung universe.  There are way behind Google and Apple in this respect.  I hope they keep updating their apps to better more useful ones, because right now, they are not that great. Overall I love this watch.  I am very happy I decided to try this out.  It really does make me think how I lived without one for so long.

I have had this watch for I think 2 years now, and this watch has been amazing, the bezel works very seamlessly, the UI is very smooth and works very well. The system with the phone is very nice I can use it to track fitness, my music, phone calls. Plus it even has a speaker in it so you can answer calls and listen to music through the watch speaker if you need. The apps you can get are an amazing never ending feature. It runs off of the galaxy store but your not limited at all. So many useful apps to choose from and a list that keeps expanding makes it never get old. I highly reccomend this watch, just aware that Bezel is not super FL against the watch so if you spill something on it you might get something inside of it that can make it feel sticky or just stop moving. But it's okay it's waterproof so washing it in the sink whilst moving the bezel cleans it right up like it's brand new. My only gripe is it's battery at first I could get almost 2 days out of the watch now I have to charge it every night. But other than that it works very well and highly reccomned it.

I love my Samsung Galaxy Watch! When I was looking for smart watches, I was tempted to buy the Samsung Galaxy Watch Active which was just launched back then. However, that one didn't had all the features that makes this one a great smartwatch. I love being able to pick up a call and talk through the watch, people hear me perfectly and I hear them very well. In addition, when I'm home I connect to WiFi rather than bluetooth, it gives me a greater range and watch does not disconnect when I leave the phone in another room. Pros:
-Amazing battery time, can last over a week depending on use. (For example, only connecting BT when not home).
-Tracks my stress levels several times a day, it is accurate. Has a relaxation feature with breathing exercises. LOVE IT.
-Tracks my BPM, accurate but you need to stay still.
-Samsung Health is a good app. I track my bike rides and it syncs with the phone app without any issues. I have yet to use Strava.
-Alarms! But also, alarms set on the phone only will also go off on the watch. So no need to have alarms set on watch and phone. BT or WiFi needs to be connected for this.
-SmartThings: can control my Samsung Smart TV from my watch (WiFi connected)
-Can control Spotify
-Find my phone and find my watch functions. Basic functions:
-Step counter, not incredible accurate but then again I haven't tried any other device for this.
-Calories burned during exercise.
-Actual watch, wide range of faces to choose from. Analog, digital, combined, there is a watch face for every taste. Things I have not tried:
-Sleep tracking. I mean, the watch is comfortable and all, but I cannot sleep with any accessory on. Some cons, not a big deal for me:
-GPS seems to be a little unrealiable.
-Sometimes when measuring BPM or stress (which is measure based on BPM) the watch would give an error and ask you to clean the sensor.
-That same sensor, will go off when you are not wearing the watch, presumably for the automatic BPM and stress measures, but it should have a way to tell you are not wearing it and not try again and again. But the cons are not a deal breaker for me. Maybe I'm doing something wrong or not using it as I should. Anyway, completely recommend this smartwatch even after there is a newer version out there. I don't think the newer ones have this amazing battery life and versatility this one has. That is all, hope this helps. Oh, remember to pair with a Samsung phone to enjoy ALL the features. ??

A couple of quick notes before I get into the review: -I'm reviewing the 42mm version, which I've had for about 3 weeks now.
-Apple vs. Samsung comparisons are overblown; both are good watches, but obviously you should match your watch to your phone
-I don't think there's a better smartwatch available at the moment, but I'm only giving this watch 4 stars because I don't think smartwatch technology has fully matured at this stage; I'd say there are no 5 star smartwatches at the moment Bottom line: The Galaxy Watch does almost everything I was hoping for, and does it pretty well
-My settings: AoD on with a simple face, brightness 3, location off, HR every 10 min, voice activation off; I use the watch whenever I'm away from home – appx 11hrs/day
-With those settings and that usage pattern, I get through 2 days on a charge with a bit to spare
-Reading and responding to notifications is smooth
-Overall, I'd say the exercise tracking is pretty good, not great
-Step counting seems accurate for walking at a reasonable pace, but inaccurate for slow walking or a mix of walking/standing (such as when moving through a museum)
-I mainly use S Health for HR tracking, which works well for steady state cardio but less well for weight training. I'm not sure if it’s thrown off by rapid fluctuations in my HR, moving around a bit on wrist during exercise, or what, but it often loses track of my HR, lags behind spikes and dips, and doesn’t seem to reach true peaks
-For weight lifting, S health isn’t that useful; it can’t count reps on that many exercises and doesn't allow for custom workout design
-I use an app (gymrun) that allows custom workout design; it doesn’t track HR or count reps, but you can manually enter reps and use S health (on ‘other workout’) to track HR
